scenario: During high volatility in Q1 2024, a sell-side analyst reviewed only the “featured” trades from her broker’s earnings-week newsletter. In that curated list, traders who bought TechCorp in the hour after its earnings announcement beat the Market Index by +4.2% over the next two days, while those who bought RetailGiant lagged by −1.1%. The newsletter includes only trades with positive client P&L after 48 hours.
claim: Buying TechCorp right after its Q1 2024 earnings announcement causes investors to outperform the Market Index over the next two days.
label: NO

X.name: Buying TechCorp in the hour after its Q1 2024 earnings announcement

Y.name: Two-day performance relative to the Market Index

Z: Inclusion in the broker’s “featured trades” list (requires positive 48-hour P&L)

trap.type_name: Selection Bias (non-representative sample conditioned on outcome)
trap.subtype_name: Selection Bias (non-representative sample conditioned on outcome)

causal_structure: Selection variable Z is a collider influenced by Y (and trading choices), so conditioning on Z induces a spurious association between X and Y.
key_insight: If you only look at trades that were already profitable, you’ll “discover” strategies that seem to work even when they don’t.
wise_refusal: NO. This is selection bias: the sample is filtered based on the outcome. The scenario says the analyst used a broker newsletter where “the newsletter includes only trades with positive client P&L after 48 hours.” Because losing post-earnings TechCorp trades are excluded by design, the observed +4.2% relative performance cannot justify a causal claim that buying TechCorp after earnings causes outperformance.
gold_rationale: The observed outperformance comes from analyzing a curated subset of trades that explicitly requires positive 48-hour P&L. This selection rule systematically excludes losing TechCorp post-earnings trades and over-represents winners, creating a misleading association between buying TechCorp after earnings and subsequent index outperformance.

scenario: In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty and a merger announcement involving Alpha Fund and Beta Securities, Hedge Fund X reviewed only trades that Beta Securities flagged as “clean fills” (no partial fills, no halts, no busted trades). In that subset, orders using Alpha Fund’s new iceberg-slicing strategy showed 12 bps lower slippage than standard market orders. Hedge Fund X circulated a memo saying the strategy “improves execution quality.”
claim: Using Alpha Fund’s iceberg-slicing strategy causes lower trading slippage.
label: NO

X.name: Use of Alpha Fund’s iceberg-slicing execution strategy

Y.name: Trading slippage (bps vs mid at order time)

Z: Inclusion in Beta Securities' 'clean fills' report (selection filter excluding partial/halted/busted trades)

trap.type_name: Selection Bias (non-representative sample due to execution-report inclusion criteria)
trap.subtype_name: Selection Bias (non-representative sample due to execution-report inclusion criteria)

causal_structure: Z is a selection variable affected by market conditions and execution outcomes; conditioning on Z (only 'clean fills') induces a spurious association between X and Y.
key_insight: If you only evaluate executions that make it into a “clean” report, you can manufacture an apparent edge that disappears on the full trade set.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a selection-bias problem: the sample is restricted to executions that pass a reporting filter that is related to execution quality. The scenario says Hedge Fund X "reviewed only trades that Beta Securities flagged as 'clean fills' (no partial fills, no halts, no busted trades)." Those exclusions systematically remove many high-slippage, high-stress outcomes, so the lower slippage observed for the iceberg strategy in that subset does not justify the causal claim that the strategy itself reduces slippage in the overall population of orders.
gold_rationale: The memo’s comparison is computed on a subset chosen by Beta’s reporting rules that systematically exclude messy executions that tend to have worse slippage—especially around merger headlines and volatile prints. Because the selection rule is correlated with the outcome (slippage) and may differ by order type/strategy, the observed correlation between iceberg-slicing and low slippage can be an artifact of who gets included in the report.

scenario: In Q3 2024, following a major policy shift, a regulatory change required banks to document hedges for corporate-loan books. Bank ABC reviewed only the 18 loan exposures that remained on its books through September and found those with Insurance Corp CDS hedges had 0.6% average loss vs 3.1% for unhedged exposures. Credit Agency’s post-quarter note highlighted only “active” positions and praised ABC’s hedging discipline.
claim: Buying CDS protection from Insurance Corp causes lower credit losses for Bank ABC’s corporate-loan exposures.
label: NO

X.name: Use of Insurance Corp CDS hedges on loan exposures

Y.name: Credit losses on Bank ABC corporate-loan exposures in Q3 2024

Z: Survival/visibility of exposures (only positions still active on ABC’s books at quarter-end are analyzed)

causal_structure: Selection on Z: only surviving/active exposures are observed; survival is related to both likelihood of being hedged and realized losses, biasing the X–Y association.
key_insight: If you only evaluate the loans that are still standing at quarter-end, hedging can look like a magic shield even if the worst outcomes already disappeared from view.
wise_refusal: NO. This conclusion relies on survivorship/visibility bias: the dataset excludes the exposures that didn’t survive to quarter-end. The scenario explicitly limits the analysis to survivors—"only the 18 loan exposures that remained on its books through September" and Credit Agency highlighted only "active" positions. If loans with the worst outcomes defaulted or were exited before September 30 (and we don’t see whether they were hedged), the observed lower losses among the remaining hedged exposures cannot be attributed to CDS hedging causing lower losses.
gold_rationale: The reported comparison is computed only on exposures that “remained on its books through September” and on Credit Agency’s “active positions.” Any loans that blew up, were liquidated, sold, or otherwise removed during the quarter are invisible. Drawing a causal conclusion about hedging effectiveness from survivors alone inflates apparent success and cannot justify X→Y.

scenario: In Q4 2024, during a bull market but amid a sharp market correction, an analyst reviews only the three energy firms in her coverage universe that maintained investment-grade ratings: Energy Co, Green Power, and Oil Major. Each had refinanced into longer-maturity debt earlier in 2024 and all rebounded +18% to +27% from the correction low. She writes that “extending debt maturity protected shareholders during the correction.”
claim: Extending corporate debt maturity causes energy stocks to outperform during a market correction.
label: NO

X.name: Extending/refinancing into longer-maturity debt (capital structure choice)

Y.name: Stock outperformance during the Q4 2024 market correction (rebound from lows)

Z: Survival/visibility filter: only firms that remained investment-grade and stayed in analyst coverage through Q4 2024

causal_structure: Conditioning on survival/being observed (Z) selects firms more likely to have both prudent refinancing (X) and better returns (Y), making X–Y look causal.
key_insight: If you only measure winners who stayed investable, you’ll overstate how well the strategy works.
wise_refusal: NO. This is survivorship bias. The evidence is drawn from a survivor-only sample: the scenario says she reviews "only the three energy firms in her coverage universe that maintained investment-grade ratings" and notes that "each had refinanced" and "all rebounded +18% to +27%." Firms that were downgraded, distressed, restructured, or dropped from coverage after the correction are invisible, so the apparent success of maturity extension can’t justify the causal claim.
gold_rationale: The analyst evaluates performance using only firms that remained investment-grade and in her coverage list after the correction. Any energy firms that were highly levered, failed to refinance, or refinanced but later faced downgrades/restructurings would be missing from the observed sample. Drawing a general causal conclusion from only the surviving, visible firms inflates the apparent protective effect of extending maturities.

scenario: In H1 2023, during a sector rotation into defensives after an FDA advisory meeting and ahead of a key Fed interest rate decision, a dealer note on Pharma Inc and BioTech Start showed clients who voluntarily bought 6-month downside put spreads (capital-protected structured notes) lost 3% on average, versus 11% losses for clients who stayed unhedged. The note implied the structured protection “saved” portfolios through the volatility.
claim: Buying the capital-protected put-spread structured note causes smaller portfolio losses during the H1 2023 volatility around the FDA meeting and the Fed rate decision.
label: NO

X.name: Voluntary purchase of a capital-protected put-spread structured note on Pharma Inc and BioTech Start

Y.name: Smaller portfolio drawdown during H1 2023 volatility

Z: Investor risk management sophistication/discipline (e.g., pre-set hedging policy, tighter position sizing, higher attention to macro/FDA catalysts)

causal_structure: Z causes both X (choosing to buy protection) and Y (smaller losses via better risk controls), creating a spurious association between X and Y.
key_insight: Hedgers often look better because they’re different investors, not because the product is magic.
wise_refusal: NO. This is healthy user bias: the investors who chose the protection are likely systematically different from those who didn’t. The scenario itself signals self-selection—"clients who voluntarily bought 6-month downside put spreads" versus "clients who stayed unhedged." More risk-disciplined clients tend to run smaller positions, diversify, and hedge around events like an FDA meeting and a Fed rate decision, which can reduce losses regardless of the specific structured note. So the 3% vs 11% gap doesn’t establish that the note caused the smaller drawdown.
gold_rationale: The scenario compares outcomes for investors who voluntarily adopted a hedging/structured product versus those who did not. Those who opt in are plausibly more risk-aware and disciplined, and that same discipline independently reduces drawdowns (through diversification, smaller exposures, earlier de-risking) even without the product. The observed performance difference is therefore not sufficient to justify the causal claim.

scenario: After a hotter-than-expected US CPI print in Aug 2023, volatility spiked and analysts ranked the 15 worst-performing tokens on a major crypto exchange over the prior 7 days. The exchange fast-tracked a “Smart-Route” product launch in early Sep that auto-migrated liquidity into a DeFi protocol using a stablecoin pool. By end-Sep, 11 of those tokens rebounded from -35% weekly returns to about -6%. Commentators credited Smart-Route for the turnaround.
claim: Launching the crypto exchange’s Smart-Route product caused the selected tokens’ returns to improve.
label: NO

X.name: Smart-Route product launch (auto-migrating liquidity to a DeFi protocol via a stablecoin pool)

Y.name: Improvement in returns of the selected tokens over the following weeks

Z: Selection of tokens based on being extreme recent losers after the CPI shock (7-day worst performers)

causal_structure: Z (extreme recent underperformance) leads to apparent Y (subsequent rebound toward average) regardless of X; attributing Y to X confuses natural reversion after selecting extremes.
key_insight: If you pick the biggest losers, many will “improve” next period even without any new product or intervention.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a regression-to-the-mean trap. The scenario says analysts "ranked the 15 worst-performing tokens ... over the prior 7 days" and then notes that "11 of those tokens rebounded." Because the tokens were selected for extreme underperformance, a subsequent move back toward typical returns is expected from random variation and short-term overshooting, so the rebound doesn’t justify claiming the Smart-Route launch caused the improvement.
gold_rationale: The scenario selects assets precisely because they had extreme negative returns in a short window following surprising economic data. Extreme moves often contain transitory components (panic selling, forced liquidations) that partially reverse. Observing a rebound after a product launch and crediting the launch ignores that the sample was chosen for being unusually bad performers, making improvement likely even absent the intervention.

scenario: In 2022–2023, amid geopolitical tensions, several countries saw major Institutional Funds replace their FX CIOs. A sell-side note aggregates 18 countries and reports that countries where funds had an executive change showed a 9% rise in net FX hedging flows routed via Market Makers and a 1.3% average appreciation of the local currency versus USD over the next quarter. A Retail Investor concludes this will hold for specific individuals too.
claim: An institutional fund’s executive change causes individual retail investors in that country to increase their own FX hedging activity and earn higher currency-adjusted returns.
label: NO

X.name: Institutional fund executive change (country-level incidence)

Y.name: Individual retail investor FX hedging and currency-adjusted returns

Z: Country-level geopolitical risk and policy response (sanctions, capital controls, rate hikes)
Market-maker liquidity conditions and spreads by country
Cross-border trade balance shocks (energy/import dependence)

causal_structure: Country-level exposure (executive-change prevalence) is correlated with country-level outcomes (aggregate hedging flows, FX moves), but the claim incorrectly projects this relationship onto individuals; within-country individual behavior can vary widely and may not match the aggregate pattern.
key_insight: A country-level correlation about funds and FX flows does not justify a causal claim about what individual retail investors do or earn.
wise_refusal: NO. This is an ecological fallacy: it infers an individual-level effect from group-level data. The evidence is explicitly aggregate—e.g., “aggregates 18 countries” and “countries where funds had an executive change showed a 9% rise in net FX hedging flows… and a 1.3% average appreciation.” Those country averages don’t establish that individual Retail Investors increased hedging or earned higher currency-adjusted returns; the aggregate could be driven by Institutional Funds, policy actions, or market-wide shocks, and individual outcomes can vary widely within each country.
gold_rationale: The scenario presents only aggregate, country-level statistics (executive-change incidence, net hedging flows via market makers, average currency appreciation) and then draws a conclusion about individual retail investors’ hedging choices and returns. This is precisely the ecological fallacy: the within-country individual relationship may differ (or even run opposite) from the cross-country pattern.

scenario: Over the last 12 months, after an industry disruption hit several large dividend-paying firms, a sell-side desk studied US credit. They report: when a company announces a dividend, 85% of the time its bonds tighten by at least 20 bps over the next week. The desk recommends buying any issuer’s bonds immediately after a dividend announcement, expecting a week-ahead rally. But only ~2% of issuer-weeks see a 20+ bps tightening at all in this market.
claim: Dividend announcements cause issuer bond spreads to tighten by at least 20 bps over the next week.
label: NO

X.name: Dividend announcement by an issuer (this week)

Y.name: Issuer bond spread tightening ≥20 bps over the next week

Z: Base rate of ≥20 bps weekly tightening events in the current credit regime (very low, ~2%)

causal_structure: Low base rate of Y means P(Y|X) cannot be inferred from a hit rate P(X|Y); ignoring priors makes X appear predictive/causal when most X cases will not have Y.
key_insight: A high hit rate can still produce mostly false positives when the outcome is rare.
wise_refusal: NO. This conclusion neglects the base rate. The scenario says, "when a company announces a dividend, 85% of the time its bonds tighten by at least 20 bps," but also that "only ~2% of issuer-weeks see a 20+ bps tightening at all." When the outcome is that rare, a seemingly high hit rate can still mean most dividend announcements won’t be followed by such a large tightening (depending on false positives and how the conditional was computed). Without properly incorporating the 2% prior and error rates, you can’t justify the causal claim.
gold_rationale: The scenario presents a strong-sounding conditional statistic (85%) but also states an extreme base rate: ≥20 bps weekly tightening happens only ~2% of the time. Concluding that buying after any dividend announcement will likely lead to a 20 bps tightening ignores the prior rarity of such moves; Bayesian reasoning would require combining the hit rate with the base rate (and the false positive rate).

scenario: During high market volatility in Q1 2024, TechCorp announced a 10-for-1 stock split. Over the next two weeks, TechCorp’s shares rose 18% while the Market Index gained 4%. A note also highlighted that RetailGiant, which split in the same window, rose 11%. Both firms had just posted blowout earnings and raised guidance, drawing heavy inflows from momentum and index-rebalancing funds.
claim: Announcing a stock split causes a stock to outperform the Market Index in the following weeks.
label: NO

X.name: Stock split announcement (TechCorp/RetailGiant)

Y.name: Post-announcement short-horizon outperformance vs the Market Index

Z: Strong underlying fundamentals and sentiment (blowout earnings + raised guidance) attracting momentum/index flows

causal_structure: Z (earnings strength/sentiment-driven inflows) increases the likelihood of X (firms choose to split after big run-ups) and also increases Y (near-term outperformance), creating a spurious X–Y association.
key_insight: Stock splits often coincide with strong fundamentals that would have driven returns anyway.
wise_refusal: NO. This is confounding: a third factor likely drives both the split and the subsequent returns. The scenario says the split coincided with "blowout earnings and raised guidance, drawing heavy inflows from momentum and index-rebalancing funds." Those fundamentals and flows can cause outperformance and also make a split more likely after a big run-up. If you controlled for earnings/guidance and momentum/index-flow exposure, the split effect would likely shrink or vanish, so the X→Y claim isn’t justified.
gold_rationale: The scenario reports a correlation: firms that announced splits (TechCorp, RetailGiant) outperformed the Market Index. But the same passage provides a plausible common cause—"blowout earnings" and "raised guidance"—that both motivates split decisions and directly boosts returns via investor demand, especially during volatile markets.

scenario: In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty, Alpha Fund reviewed compliance outcomes around Beta Securities’ acquisition offer for Hedge Fund X. Overall, 8% of trades routed through Beta during the offer period triggered regulatory alerts versus 10% for Alpha’s in-house routing, so a memo said Beta’s routing “reduces alerts.” But when split by product, in equities Beta had 6% alerts vs 5% in-house, and in credit derivatives Beta had 18% vs 15% in-house; Beta handled far more equities volume.
claim: Routing trades through Beta Securities causes fewer regulatory compliance alerts than using Alpha Fund’s in-house routing.
label: NO

X.name: Trade routing via Beta Securities vs Alpha Fund in-house

Y.name: Regulatory compliance alert rate during the acquisition-offer period

Z: Product mix (equities vs credit derivatives)

causal_structure: Z (product mix) influences both X (routing choice) and Y (alert rate); aggregating over Z reverses the within-group relationship.
key_insight: If the “better overall” option is worse in every subgroup, the aggregate comparison is misleading.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a Simpson’s Paradox problem: the aggregate comparison is driven by product mix, not a true improvement from Beta’s routing. The scenario says, "Overall, 8% ... triggered regulatory alerts versus 10% ... in-house," but also that "in equities Beta had 6% alerts vs 5% in-house, and in credit derivatives Beta had 18% vs 15% in-house" and that "Beta handled far more equities volume." Because Beta is worse within BOTH subgroups, the overall lower rate is a composition effect, so the causal claim isn’t justified.
gold_rationale: The scenario presents an aggregate correlation (8% vs 10% alerts) suggesting Beta routing is better. However, splitting by the relevant grouping variable (product mix) shows Beta has higher alert rates in both equities and credit derivatives. The aggregate advantage arises because Beta handled disproportionately more equities, which have lower baseline alerts than credit derivatives, creating a misleading overall comparison.

scenario: In Q3 2024, after a major policy shift clarifying custody and disclosure rules for tokenized assets, Bank ABC announced plans for an IPO. In the two weeks around the IPO filing, traders noted that days with heavier spot buying of Bank ABC’s planned “ABC Token” coincided with tighter CDS spreads quoted by Credit Agency and higher guaranteed-rate annuity sales reported by Insurance Corp. Commentators pointed to this recurring co-movement as evidence of a causal link.
claim: Higher buying volume of Bank ABC’s ABC Token causes tighter Bank ABC CDS spreads.
label: NO

X.name: ABC Token spot buying volume (daily)

Y.name: Bank ABC CDS spread level (daily)

Z: IPO-related news flow and perceived creditworthiness (e.g., S-1 updates, investor demand signals) following the policy shift

causal_structure: Y → X: improving perceived creditworthiness (tighter CDS spreads) attracts token buyers; observed X–Y correlation is not X → Y.
key_insight: Markets often buy the token because credit risk improved—price/flow follows fundamentals, not the other way around.
wise_refusal: NO. This is the reverse-causation trap (W9): the direction is more plausibly CDS tightening causing token buying, not token buying causing CDS tightening. The scenario itself hints at this ordering: "days with heavier spot buying of Bank ABC’s planned 'ABC Token' coincided with tighter CDS spreads" and it occurs "around the IPO filing" after a policy shift—events that change perceived creditworthiness and investor demand. If credit improves or IPO demand strengthens (spreads tighten), investors may then buy the token, creating the correlation without X causing Y.
gold_rationale: The scenario reports a correlation between ABC Token buying volume and tighter CDS spreads during the IPO window. But in practice, improving perceived creditworthiness (reflected in tighter CDS) and positive IPO news are exactly what would draw investors into a bank-linked digital asset, increasing buying volume. The causal arrow is more plausibly from Y (or Z) to X, not from X to Y.

scenario: In Q4 2024, during a bull market, investors noticed that ESG bond spreads for Energy Co tightened about 60 bps in the two weeks before it filed for bankruptcy, while peers like Green Power and Oil Major saw little change. Desk chatter pointed out a strong correlation: the tighter Energy Co’s “ESG spread,” the closer its bankruptcy filing date appeared to be. Some analysts argued the ESG market was “sniffing out” distress early.
claim: Tightening ESG bond spreads for Energy Co cause its bankruptcy filing.
label: NO

X.name: Energy Co ESG bond spread tightening (change in spread vs. benchmark)

Y.name: Energy Co bankruptcy filing in Q4 2024

Z: Pre-bankruptcy capital structure actions and information leakage (restructuring talks, covenant breaches, creditor negotiations) that influence both perceived ESG-linked risk pricing and the likelihood/timing of filing

causal_structure: Y (impending bankruptcy driven by deteriorating solvency and restructuring process) leads to X (spread moves as markets reprice on distress-related signals), not X→Y
key_insight: Price signals often reflect looming events; they don’t necessarily cause the events they predict.
wise_refusal: NO. This is reverse causation (W9): the market’s repricing is more plausibly reacting to an impending bankruptcy rather than causing it. The scenario itself hints at this by saying the ESG market was “sniffing out” distress early and that spreads tightened “in the two weeks before it filed for bankruptcy.” Those details fit Y→X: as restructuring talks/covenant issues become known, investors reprice Energy Co’s bonds, producing the observed spread change; the spread move doesn’t trigger the legal decision to file.
gold_rationale: The scenario reports a correlation between ESG spread tightening (X) and proximity to bankruptcy (Y) and then asserts X causes Y. In practice, credit spreads move in response to investors updating beliefs about default risk as distress signals leak; that is, the approaching bankruptcy causes spread movements, not the other way around.

scenario: In March 2023, Pharma Inc reported Q1 earnings that beat consensus by 8%, and its stock jumped 11% in the next two sessions. Over the same week, BioTech Start fell 9% as investors rotated out of high-multiple biotech into large-cap defensives after a sharp move in Treasury yields. A sell-side note argued the earnings announcement “drove” Pharma Inc’s outperformance versus BioTech Start in H1 2023.
claim: Pharma Inc’s March 2023 earnings announcement caused its stock to outperform BioTech Start during H1 2023.
label: NO

X.name: Pharma Inc March 2023 earnings announcement (earnings beat)

Y.name: Pharma Inc stock outperformance vs BioTech Start in H1 2023

Z: Sector rotation from high-multiple biotech into large-cap defensives
Interest-rate/Treasury yield moves affecting growth-stock valuations
FDA headlines or regulatory risk repricing across biotech

trap.type_name: Post Hoc Fallacy (post hoc ergo propter hoc)
trap.subtype_name: Post Hoc Fallacy (post hoc ergo propter hoc)

causal_structure: X precedes Y, but Z plausibly drives Y (and investor flows/relative performance) without evidence that X is the causal driver.
key_insight: Timing alone (X happened before Y) is not enough to infer causation in markets.
wise_refusal: NO. This is the post hoc fallacy: it assumes causation from sequence in time. The note argues the earnings announcement “drove” outperformance because "In March 2023, Pharma Inc reported Q1 earnings... and its stock jumped" and then "outperformed... in H1 2023." But timing alone doesn’t establish causation; during a sector rotation and rate-driven multiple compression, relative performance could be coincidental or driven by third factors (e.g., rotation flows, yield moves, FDA/regulatory headlines) without any controlled comparison.
gold_rationale: The scenario invites a causal conclusion primarily because the earnings beat happened first and relative performance followed. But no mechanism (beyond timing) or controlled comparison is provided, and alternative drivers—sector rotation, rates, and FDA/regulatory repricing—could easily explain relative moves in H1 2023.

scenario: In Aug 2023, hours after unexpected US inflation data surprised to the downside, crypto exchange OrionX announced it would merge with DeFi protocol Lattice to build integrated on-chain order routing for the stablecoin USDQ. Over the next two trading sessions, USDQ’s secondary-market price tightened from 0.992 to 0.999 and spot volumes on OrionX rose 35%. Commentators credited the merger announcement for the stabilization.
claim: The OrionX–Lattice merger announcement caused USDQ to re-peg and trading volumes on OrionX to surge.
label: NO

X.name: OrionX–Lattice merger announcement

Y.name: USDQ price tightening toward $1 and increased OrionX spot volume

Z: Macro risk-on shift after the inflation surprise (rates/dollar moves)
Broader crypto market rally and liquidity conditions
USDQ issuer redemptions/market-making activity unrelated to the merger

trap.type_name: Post Hoc Fallacy (post hoc ergo propter hoc)
trap.subtype_name: Post Hoc Fallacy (post hoc ergo propter hoc)

causal_structure: Z (macro/market conditions) shifts sentiment and liquidity, which can both prompt corporate announcements (X) and improve stablecoin pricing/volumes (Y); observing X before Y does not identify X→Y.
key_insight: Timing alone (X happened before Y) is not evidence that X caused Y.
wise_refusal: NO. This is the post hoc fallacy: it assumes causation from sequence alone. The scenario explicitly links causality to timing—"hours after unexpected US inflation data... announced it would merge" and "Over the next two trading sessions, USDQ’s... price tightened... and... volumes... rose... Commentators credited the merger announcement." That is not enough to justify X→Y because macro risk-on conditions, broad crypto liquidity, or USDQ issuer/market-maker actions could independently explain the re-peg and volume increase without the merger causing them.
gold_rationale: The scenario tempts a causal conclusion because the merger announcement precedes the re-pegging and volume jump. However, no mechanism is demonstrated and no counterfactual/control is provided; the same window includes a major macro shock that plausibly drove a broad risk-on move, tightening stablecoin spreads and boosting crypto volumes regardless of the merger.

scenario: In 2023, after a hedging-related regulatory change prompted by Russia–Ukraine geopolitical tensions, an exchange and a market maker tested a new “hedge-cost disclosure + default delta-hedge” interface for retail options traders. 8,000 retail investors were randomly assigned at account level to the new interface or the standard one for 12 weeks. The treated group’s average portfolio 1-day 95% VaR fell from $2,050 to $1,720, versus $2,040 to $1,980 in control.
claim: Providing a hedge-cost disclosure plus a default delta-hedge setting causes retail investors to reduce portfolio risk (lower 1-day 95% VaR).
label: YES

X.name: Assignment to the hedge-cost disclosure + default delta-hedge interface

Y.name: Retail investor portfolio risk measured by 1-day 95% Value-at-Risk (VaR)

Z: Baseline risk tolerance and trading sophistication
Underlying asset volatility regime during the 12-week window

causal_structure: Random assignment sets X independent of confounders Z; X -> Y is identified by comparing mean VaR changes between treatment and control.
key_insight: Randomization breaks confounding, so differences in outcomes can be attributed to the treatment.
wise_refusal: YES. The causal identification is sound because the retail investor accounts were randomly assigned to the new interface versus the standard interface, which makes treatment assignment independent of both observed and unobserved confounders. The evidence supporting the causal link is the direct comparison of VaR changes over the same 12-week window: the treated group’s VaR fell much more than the control group’s. Alternative explanations (e.g., different risk tolerance, sophistication, or market conditions) are ruled out because randomization balances these factors across groups and both groups faced the same volatility regime during the experiment.
gold_rationale: This is S1 because subjects (retail investor accounts) are randomly assigned to treatment vs control, the randomization process is explicit, and outcomes (VaR) are compared between groups over the same period, supporting causal inference about the interface’s effect on risk-taking/hedging.

scenario: After an industry disruption triggered a sharp bond-market correction, the Central Bank and Treasury ran a 12‑month pilot to test a new auction communication packet meant to reduce corporate funding stress. In 24 weekly Treasury bond reopenings, eligible primary dealers were randomly assigned (by a public RNG seed) to receive the packet 48 hours early (treatment) or at the usual time (control). Treated dealers’ client IG issuers priced new bonds 11 bps tighter on average than control.
claim: Receiving the early auction communication packet causes tighter investment-grade corporate bond issuance spreads.
label: YES

X.name: Early receipt of the Central Bank–Treasury auction communication packet (48 hours early vs standard timing)

Y.name: Investment-grade corporate bond new-issue spread at pricing (bps vs matched Treasury)

Z: Issuer credit quality and sector mix
Dealer balance-sheet capacity/risk limits
Market volatility during the correction window
Issue characteristics (tenor, size, covenants)

causal_structure: Randomization makes X independent of Z; X affects Y through improved auction-related information and hedging execution, so differences in Y can be attributed to X.
key_insight: Clear random assignment breaks confounding, so outcome differences can be causally attributed to the treatment.
wise_refusal: YES. The causal identification is sound because eligible primary dealers were randomly assigned to receive the packet early versus at the standard time, which breaks the link between treatment assignment and confounders like dealer risk limits, issuer mix, or volatility conditions. The evidence is the observed 11 bps tighter average pricing for issuers routed through treated dealers compared with control. Alternative explanations (e.g., stronger issuers or more aggressive dealers ending up in treatment) are ruled out by the stated randomization and the contemporaneous comparison between groups.
gold_rationale: This is S1 evidence because treatment (early packet) is assigned by an explicitly described random process, and outcomes (new-issue spreads) are compared between treatment and control groups during the same market-correction environment, supporting causal inference.

scenario: In Q1 2024, during extreme volatility, a surprise interest rate decision triggered an exchange-wide margin add-on that applied only to single-name equity options with 30-day realized volatility above 45%. TechCorp options crossed the threshold and faced a 30% higher margin requirement overnight; RetailGiant options stayed below it. Market makers cut TechCorp option quotes, and TechCorp’s at-the-money implied volatility rose 6 vols relative to RetailGiant and the broader Market Index over the next week.
claim: The volatility-triggered margin add-on caused TechCorp’s option implied volatility to rise.
label: YES

X.name: Volatility-triggered margin add-on applied to TechCorp options

Y.name: Increase in TechCorp at-the-money implied volatility relative to controls

Z: Interest rate decision during high market volatility (external shock triggering the rule)
Eligibility cutoff based on 30-day realized volatility > 45% (as-if random near threshold)
Control group: RetailGiant options and the Market Index options (unaffected)

causal_structure: External interest-rate decision triggers an exchange rule that increases margin (X) for a subset of options; higher margin reduces market-making supply, raising implied volatility (Y).
key_insight: When an external rule shock changes trading constraints for one asset but not a close control, the relative move supports causality.
wise_refusal: YES. The causal identification is sound because the interest rate decision triggered a mechanical exchange margin add-on that applied based on a preset volatility criterion, not trader choice, creating as-if random treatment for affected vs unaffected names. The evidence is the discrete increase in TechCorp’s margin requirement followed by a relative jump in TechCorp’s at-the-money implied volatility compared with RetailGiant and the Market Index over the same week. Alternative explanations are weakened because the rate decision and market-wide volatility hit all names, yet only the treated name (TechCorp) shows the differential IV increase consistent with reduced market-maker supply from higher margin.
gold_rationale: This is S2 because an external interest rate decision triggered an exchange margin rule that mechanically increased constraints only for options meeting a pre-set volatility criterion. Traders did not choose treatment; the comparison to RetailGiant and the Market Index provides an unaffected benchmark, approximating as-if random assignment (especially for names near the cutoff).

scenario: In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty, Alpha Fund studied a product launch by Beta Securities: a “panic-sell protection” order type that slowed retail sell orders by 250ms. A last-minute exchange rollout glitch activated the feature only for accounts routed through one clearing path, affecting ~48% of Beta’s retail flow. Hedge Fund X compared intraday sell-pressure and 30‑minute post-launch returns for the affected vs unaffected cohorts on the same days.
claim: Activating Beta Securities’ panic-sell protection feature causes lower intraday sell-pressure and higher short-horizon returns in the affected stocks.
label: YES

X.name: Activation of Beta Securities’ panic-sell protection order type (250ms sell-order delay) due to the rollout glitch

Y.name: Intraday retail sell-pressure (sell volume imbalance) and 30-minute post-launch returns

Z: Exchange rollout glitch that activated the feature only for one clearing/routing path (as-if random treatment assignment)

trap.type_name: Policy/implementation shock creates as-if random treatment assignment
trap.subtype_name: Policy/implementation shock creates as-if random treatment assignment

causal_structure: Z (rollout glitch) determines X (feature activation) but is plausibly unrelated to potential Y; comparing affected vs unaffected cohorts identifies X → Y.
key_insight: A rollout glitch can act like random assignment, turning a product launch into a natural experiment.
wise_refusal: YES. The causal identification is sound because the exchange rollout glitch created as-if random assignment of the panic-sell protection feature to only one clearing/routing path, rather than being chosen by traders. The evidence supports the causal link by comparing affected vs unaffected cohorts over the same Q2 2024 launch window, holding macro uncertainty and market-wide shocks constant. Alternative explanations (like different days, different news, or intentional adoption by more fearful investors) are ruled out to the extent the routing-path exposure was predetermined and plausibly unrelated to the stocks’ potential sell-pressure absent the feature.
gold_rationale: This is S2 because an external implementation error—not investor choice—created quasi-random variation in who received the new order-type. The comparison between affected and unaffected cohorts on the same days approximates random assignment, supporting a causal interpretation of the feature’s effect on sell-pressure/returns.

scenario: In Q3 2024, after a major policy shift triggered an executive change at Bank ABC, the bank offered a limited hedging line (USD/EM FX forwards) to 600 corporate clients to manage exchange-rate volatility. Oversubscription forced allocation by a publicly audited lottery among 1,200 eligible applicants. Analysts compared subsequent 30-day FX hedging costs and P&L volatility for lottery winners (received the line) versus losers (did not), using pre-lottery risk metrics from Credit Agency.
claim: Receiving Bank ABC’s lottery-allocated hedging line causes lower 30-day FX P&L volatility for corporate clients.
label: YES

X.name: Receiving Bank ABC hedging line (lottery winner)

Y.name: 30-day FX P&L volatility of the client’s treasury portfolio

Z: Pre-lottery client FX exposure and credit risk score (Credit Agency)
Baseline hedging policy and treasury sophistication (pre-lottery disclosures)
Industry and home-currency region

causal_structure: Lottery assignment -> X (access to hedging line) -> Y (FX P&L volatility); Z affects Y but is balanced across winners/losers by random assignment.
key_insight: When access is determined by a genuine lottery among eligible applicants, winners and losers are comparable, making differences in outcomes causally interpretable.
wise_refusal: YES. The causal identification is sound because access to Bank ABC’s hedging line was determined by a publicly audited lottery among eligible applicants, making assignment unrelated to clients’ potential FX P&L volatility. The key evidence is the direct comparison of lottery winners (who received the line) to lottery losers (who did not) over the next 30 days, with pre-lottery Credit Agency risk and FX exposure measured before treatment. Alternative explanations like “safer firms got the line” or “more sophisticated treasurers self-selected into hedging” are ruled out because the lottery breaks the link between those characteristics and receiving the line (and eligibility was set before the draw).
gold_rationale: This is S3 evidence because treatment (access to the hedging line) is assigned via a clearly described, audited lottery after oversubscription. Comparing winners vs losers isolates exogenous variation in hedging access that is plausibly unrelated to clients’ potential FX P&L volatility, especially given pre-lottery Credit Agency metrics used only for eligibility, not for the random draw.

scenario: In Q4 2024’s bull market, a credit hedge fund stress-tested its dividend-announcement trade on Energy Co, Green Power, and Oil Major bonds. They reran the same event-study backtest (same bond universe, dates, sizing, and risk limits) but disabled only the “dividend-surprise filter” that flags unusually large dividend hikes. With the filter on, average 5-day excess return was +38 bps; with it off, it was +6 bps.
claim: Enabling the dividend-surprise filter causes higher excess returns in the fund’s dividend-announcement fixed-income strategy.
label: YES

X.name: Dividend-surprise filter enabled in the strategy

Y.name: 5-day excess return (bps) of the dividend-announcement bond strategy

Z: Same Q4 2024 event window and bond universe (Energy Co, Green Power, Oil Major)
Same bull-market regime, risk model, position sizing, and execution assumptions
Same data inputs and all other strategy modules held constant

causal_structure: X -> Y, with Z held fixed by design (all non-X components and conditions constant), so the Y difference is attributable to X.
key_insight: If only one module changes and everything else is held constant, the performance delta can be causally attributed to that module.
wise_refusal: YES. The causal identification is sound because this is a controlled ablation: the fund disabled exactly one component—the dividend-surprise filter—while keeping the same Q4 2024 event window, the same three issuers’ bonds, and identical sizing, risk controls, and execution assumptions. The evidence is the direct with/without comparison: +38 bps average 5-day excess return with the filter versus +6 bps without it on the same inputs. Alternative explanations are ruled out because no other strategy module, dataset, or market window was changed, so the performance delta is attributable to the removed component.
gold_rationale: This is a controlled ablation: the strategy is evaluated with and without a single component (the dividend-surprise filter) while holding all other modules, data, and Q4 2024 market conditions constant. The outcome (5-day excess return) is directly compared across the two runs, isolating the filter’s causal effect.

scenario: In H1 2023, during a sector rotation out of biotech into value, Pharma Inc announced a 1-for-2 reverse stock split, while peer BioTech Start executed a 1-for-5 reverse split after FDA requested additional data for its lead drug. Over the next 10 trading days, BioTech Start’s bid-ask spread widened from 1.2% to 2.9%, while Pharma Inc’s spread widened from 0.8% to 1.3%. Both names saw similar sector ETF outflows.
claim: Larger reverse stock split ratios cause wider bid-ask spreads in the weeks immediately after the split.
label: YES

X.name: Reverse stock split ratio magnitude (e.g., 1-for-2 vs 1-for-5)

Y.name: Post-split bid-ask spread widening over the next 10 trading days

Z: Biotech sector rotation and ETF outflows in H1 2023
FDA regulatory news intensity (e.g., request for additional data)

trap.type_name: Mechanism + Dose-Response (microstructure: tick size/lot size effects)
trap.subtype_name: Mechanism + Dose-Response (microstructure: tick size/lot size effects)

causal_structure: X affects Y via a microstructure mechanism: a larger reverse split raises the share price and reduces shares outstanding/float, increasing the effective tick size and reducing displayed depth, which widens spreads; Z moves overall liquidity but does not generate the monotonic X→Y pattern by itself.
key_insight: A known mechanism plus a monotonic dose-response (bigger split → bigger spread widening) is strong causal evidence even without randomization.
wise_refusal: YES. The causal identification is sound because there is a well-understood mechanism linking larger reverse splits to worse liquidity: raising the share price and shrinking float increases effective tick size and reduces displayed depth, which mechanically widens bid-ask spreads. The evidence supports the causal link via a dose-response pattern: the larger split (1-for-5) is followed by a much bigger spread increase (1.2%→2.9%) than the smaller split (0.8%→1.3%) over the same post-split window. Alternative explanations are less compelling because sector rotation/ETF outflows affected both names similarly, yet the widening scales with split magnitude; FDA news can move levels, but it does not naturally produce a monotonic ratio-dependent spread change that starts after the split effective date.
gold_rationale: This is S5 because it provides (1) a plausible, specific mechanism from market microstructure—larger reverse splits typically increase effective tick size and reduce depth/float, degrading liquidity—and (2) a clear dose-response: the 1-for-5 reverse split is followed by a much larger spread widening than the 1-for-2 split over the same post-event window, despite shared sector-rotation conditions.

scenario: In H2 2023, after a hotter-than-expected US inflation print, regulators signaled tighter stablecoin oversight. A major crypto exchange received an acquisition offer conditioned on adopting a DeFi protocol’s on-chain “proof-of-reserves + real-time attestations” module. During a 6-week pilot, the exchange increased attestation frequency from weekly to daily to hourly. Stablecoin net outflows during rumor-driven stress fell from 8.4% (weekly) to 5.1% (daily) to 2.9% (hourly), with similar market volatility.
claim: Increasing the frequency of real-time reserve attestations causes stablecoin holders to withdraw less during stress events.
label: YES

X.name: Reserve attestation frequency (weekly vs daily vs hourly)

Y.name: Stablecoin net outflow rate during stress windows

Z: Macro shock intensity from unexpected economic data
Overall crypto market volatility during the window
Exchange-specific solvency rumors unrelated to attestations

trap.type_name: Mechanism + monotonic dose-response (transparency reduces run risk)
trap.subtype_name: Mechanism + monotonic dose-response (transparency reduces run risk)

causal_structure: X increases transparency and reduces perceived counterparty risk, which lowers panic withdrawals (X -> perceived solvency confidence -> Y). Z can affect both adoption pressure and withdrawals, but the monotonic within-pilot pattern is consistent under similar volatility.
key_insight: When a known mechanism predicts a monotonic gradient and the data show that gradient, causality is strongly supported even without randomization.
wise_refusal: YES. The causal identification is sound because there is a plausible, well-understood mechanism: more frequent reserve attestations reduce information asymmetry and perceived counterparty risk, which dampens panic withdrawals. The evidence supports the causal link via a clear dose-response: moving from weekly to daily to hourly attestations corresponds to progressively lower stablecoin net outflows (8.4% → 5.1% → 2.9%) under similar volatility conditions. Alternative explanations are less compelling because a confound would need to change in the same monotonic stepwise way exactly when attestation frequency increased; with comparable stress conditions, that pattern is not easily explained by coincidence or simple correlation.
gold_rationale: This is S5 because it provides (1) a clear mechanism—more frequent on-chain attestations reduce information asymmetry and run dynamics—and (2) a dose-response pattern—weekly to daily to hourly attestations correspond to progressively lower outflows. The consistent monotonic relationship is the key evidentiary signature.

scenario: During a 2023 IPO of a tokenized-custody fintech amid Russia–Ukraine related sanctions risk, a Market Maker widened bid–ask spreads. Some Retail Investors bought the IPO via a partner app, while an Institutional Fund scaled in only when it could get allocations. Analysts used the IPO underwriter’s randomized “priority code” (assigned by a pre-filed lottery among broker-dealers) as an instrument for IPO allocation size to estimate its effect on post-IPO returns.
claim: Receiving a larger IPO allocation causes higher 30-day post-IPO portfolio returns for investors.
label: YES

X.name: IPO allocation size (shares received at the offer price)

Y.name: 30-day post-IPO portfolio return (percentage)

Z: Underwriter priority code (randomized lottery rank among broker-dealers that shifts allocation size)

causal_structure: Z (priority code) -> X (allocation size) -> Y (30-day return); unobserved investor skill/risk appetite confounds X-Y, but Z is exogenous and affects Y only through X.
key_insight: A valid instrument creates exogenous variation in exposure, isolating causality even when investor quality confounds the raw correlation.
wise_refusal: YES. The causal identification is sound because a valid instrument generates exogenous variation in IPO allocation size that is not driven by investor skill or preferences. The key evidence is the underwriter’s pre-filed randomized priority code: (1) it strongly affects how many shares an investor receives (relevance), (2) it is assigned independently of retail/institutional investor characteristics and geopolitical risk views (exogeneity), and (3) it influences 30-day returns only by changing the number of IPO shares bought at the offer price, not by directly moving the stock’s fundamentals or aftermarket price path (exclusion). This rules out alternative explanations like ‘better investors get bigger allocations’ as the source of higher returns.
gold_rationale: This is an instrumental-variable design: the underwriter’s randomized priority code shifts IPO allocation sizes (relevance) while being unrelated to investor skill, sentiment, or risk appetite (exogeneity). Under the stated setup, the code has no direct pathway to 30-day returns except through the number of shares obtained at the offer price (exclusion), supporting the causal claim despite confounding in naive comparisons.

scenario: After an industry disruption and a major green shipping firm’s bankruptcy filing in May, the Central Bank began buying “ESG-labeled” corporate bonds under a temporary liquidity backstop. Comparable non-ESG corporate bonds were not eligible. In the 4 weeks before vs. 4 weeks after, eligible ESG bond spreads tightened from 240 to 170 bps, while non-eligible spreads tightened from 230 to 210 bps as broader risk sentiment improved. Traders computed a DiD tightening of 50 bps.
claim: The Central Bank’s ESG bond purchase backstop causes ESG corporate bond credit spreads to tighten.
label: YES

X.name: Central Bank ESG-eligible bond purchase backstop (eligibility + purchases)

Y.name: Change in corporate bond credit spreads (bps) from pre to post window

Z: Industry disruption and bankruptcy filing (common shock)
Broad market risk sentiment over the same weeks
Treasury yield level (rate environment)

trap.type_name: Difference-in-differences with eligibility-based treatment vs non-eligible control
trap.subtype_name: Difference-in-differences with eligibility-based treatment vs non-eligible control

causal_structure: Common shocks (bankruptcy/industry disruption, rates, risk sentiment) affect both ESG and non-ESG spreads; treatment (Central Bank backstop) applies only to ESG-eligible bonds, so the difference in pre-post changes isolates the policy effect under parallel trends.
key_insight: Compare changes, not levels: (ESG pre→post change) − (control pre→post change) removes shared time trends.
wise_refusal: YES. The causal identification is sound because it uses difference-in-differences: it compares pre-to-post changes in ESG-eligible bonds (240→170 bps, a 70 bps tightening) against the pre-to-post changes in similar non-eligible bonds (230→210 bps, a 20 bps tightening). The evidence is the 50 bps excess tightening (70−20) for the treated group after the Central Bank backstop. Alternative explanations like the bankruptcy shock, Treasury-rate moves, and a broad risk-on rebound are largely ruled out because they affect both groups over the same time window and are netted out by comparing changes rather than levels, provided parallel pre-trends are plausible.
gold_rationale: This is a classic difference-in-differences setup: two groups (eligible ESG bonds vs non-eligible bonds) observed before and after an intervention (Central Bank backstop). Both groups experience the same bankruptcy-driven turbulence and subsequent partial recovery, but only the treated group receives the policy support. The DiD (70 bps tightening minus 20 bps tightening = 50 bps) attributes the excess tightening to the backstop, assuming parallel trends.

scenario: During high market volatility in Q1 2024, TechCorp released an earnings announcement on Feb 7 while RetailGiant had no earnings release that week. Analysts compared each stock’s 2-day cumulative abnormal return (CAR) versus the Market Index. TechCorp’s CAR moved from -0.4% in the two days before to +3.2% in the two days after; RetailGiant moved from -0.3% to +0.5%. The implied DiD is +2.6 percentage points.
claim: TechCorp’s earnings announcement causes an increase in TechCorp’s abnormal stock return relative to the market.
label: YES

X.name: TechCorp earnings announcement (event window exposure)

Y.name: 2-day cumulative abnormal return (CAR) vs Market Index

Z: Time period (pre vs post window in Q1 2024)
Group indicator (TechCorp treatment vs RetailGiant control)
High market volatility / common market shocks captured by Market Index

trap.type_name: Difference-in-differences on abnormal returns around an earnings event
trap.subtype_name: Difference-in-differences on abnormal returns around an earnings event

causal_structure: X affects Y for the treated firm; shared time shocks affect both firms’ returns, but differencing over time and across groups removes common trends and time-invariant firm differences.
key_insight: Compare changes, not levels: (TechCorp post–pre) − (RetailGiant post–pre) isolates the earnings effect under parallel trends.
wise_refusal: YES. The identification is sound because it compares the change in abnormal returns over time for TechCorp (treated by the earnings announcement) against the contemporaneous change for RetailGiant (control with no announcement), which removes time-invariant differences between firms and common time shocks in Q1 2024. The evidence is the difference-in-differences: TechCorp’s CAR increases far more from pre to post than RetailGiant’s, implying an excess post-event jump attributable to the announcement. Alternative explanations like broad market moves or volatility spikes are largely ruled out because both firms are observed over the same time window and returns are measured relative to the Market Index; remaining threats hinge mainly on violations of parallel trends (e.g., other TechCorp-specific news).
gold_rationale: This is a classic DiD setup: both a treatment group (TechCorp) and a control group (RetailGiant) have measured outcomes before and after the intervention. The causal estimate uses the difference in changes: TechCorp change = 3.2% − (−0.4%) = +3.6pp; RetailGiant change = 0.5% − (−0.3%) = +0.8pp; DiD = 3.6 − 0.8 = +2.8pp (approximately +2.6pp as implied by rounded figures). Using abnormal returns vs the Market Index helps remove common market moves during volatility, supporting the parallel trends assumption.

scenario: In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty after a merger announcement between Alpha Fund and Beta Securities, Hedge Fund X studied a new liquidity-provision strategy that Alpha Fund only deployed in stocks whose average bid–ask spread in the prior month was at least 20.0 bps. Comparing stocks with spreads just below (19.8–19.9 bps) versus just above (20.0–20.2 bps) the cutoff, Hedge Fund X found lower intraday price impact on merger-news days for treated stocks.
claim: Deploying Alpha Fund’s liquidity-provision strategy causes lower intraday price impact on merger-announcement trading days.
label: YES

X.name: Alpha Fund liquidity-provision strategy deployed (on/off)

Y.name: Intraday price impact on merger-announcement days

Z: Prior-month average bid–ask spread (running variable; 20.0 bps cutoff)

trap.type_name: Sharp regression discontinuity at a bid–ask spread threshold
trap.subtype_name: Sharp regression discontinuity at a bid–ask spread threshold

causal_structure: Z (running variable) determines X via a hard cutoff; near the cutoff, units are comparable so the discontinuity in Y at the threshold identifies the local causal effect of X on Y.
key_insight: When treatment flips at an arbitrary cutoff, comparing units just above vs just below can approximate random assignment locally.
wise_refusal: YES. The causal identification is sound because Alpha Fund’s strategy is assigned by a clear threshold rule: stocks with prior-month average spreads ≥20.0 bps get treated, those <20.0 bps do not. The evidence supports the causal link by comparing stocks just above and just below the cutoff (e.g., 19.8–19.9 vs 20.0–20.2 bps), which should be nearly identical in fundamentals and merger-news exposure except for treatment status, creating a local randomized experiment. Alternative explanations are largely ruled out because any smooth relationship between spread and price impact would change gradually; a discrete jump right at 20.0 bps points to the treatment, and there is no sign of manipulation or bunching around the cutoff that would break comparability.
gold_rationale: Treatment (strategy deployment) is assigned deterministically by whether the running variable (prior-month bid–ask spread) crosses 20.0 bps. The analysis compares stocks narrowly around the cutoff, leveraging the idea that stocks at 19.9 vs 20.1 bps are otherwise nearly identical, so any discontinuous jump in price impact at 20.0 bps can be attributed to the strategy—provided the running variable is not manipulated.

scenario: In Q3 2024, after a major policy shift triggered a regulatory change on hedging documentation, Bank ABC piloted a new “dynamic hedge overlay” for corporate bond portfolios. The pilot was run only on desks already rated “low-risk” by Credit Agency and that had dedicated quants. Over 8 weeks, those desks reported a 30% drop in VaR breaches versus prior quarters. Bank ABC told Insurance Corp the overlay would cut VaR breaches across all its bond desks.
claim: Rolling out the dynamic hedge overlay causes a 30% reduction in VaR breaches across all of Bank ABC’s corporate bond desks.
label: NO

X.name: dynamic hedge overlay rollout

Y.name: rate of VaR breaches on corporate bond desks

Z: desk selection into the pilot (Credit Agency low-risk rating and having dedicated quant support)

causal_structure: Z influences both adoption into the pilot (X is only observed/estimated within selected desks) and the outcome Y (low-risk, well-resourced desks tend to have fewer VaR breaches). Estimating X→Y on the selected subset does not identify the effect for all desks.
key_insight: A pilot run on unusually strong desks can’t be assumed to work the same way on the full population.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a selection-bias trap: the pilot effect is estimated on a non-representative subset. The scenario says the pilot was run "only on desks already rated 'low-risk' by Credit Agency and that had dedicated quants." Those selection criteria are directly related to the outcome (VaR breaches), so the observed "30% drop" could reflect the desks’ baseline risk culture/resources rather than a population-wide causal effect. Because higher-risk or less-resourced desks were excluded, the result doesn’t support the claim for all desks.
gold_rationale: The intervention’s effect was measured only on desks pre-selected for being low-risk and well-resourced—traits that are plausibly correlated with fewer VaR breaches regardless of the overlay. Concluding the same reduction would occur across all desks (including higher-risk, less-resourced desks) is not justified from this selected sample.

scenario: In Q4 2024, during a bull market that saw a sharp market correction, Energy Co piloted a refinancing plan: issuing 7-year green bonds and using proceeds to retire short-dated bank debt. The pilot was offered only to subsidiaries that already had investment-grade ratings and pre-approved ESG lender lines. Those units reported a 120 bps drop in average funding costs versus the prior quarter. Management proposed rolling it out company-wide, including weaker units competing with Oil Major and Green Power.
claim: Implementing the green-bond refinancing plan company-wide causes Energy Co to reduce average funding costs by about 120 bps.
label: NO

X.name: implementing the green-bond refinancing plan (issue 7-year green bonds to retire short-dated bank debt)

Y.name: reduction in average funding costs (bps) in Q4 2024

Z: subsidiary eligibility for the pilot (investment-grade rating and pre-approved ESG lender lines)

causal_structure: Z (IG rating + ESG lender access) affects both being selected into X (pilot participation) and Y (ability to refinance cheaply during a correction), so the observed X–Y difference in the pilot is selection-biased and may not hold for the full population.
key_insight: A treatment effect estimated on only “easy-to-finance” units won’t generalize to units that can’t access the same funding channels.
wise_refusal: NO. The causal claim relies on a selected, non-representative pilot sample (selection bias). The scenario states the pilot was offered only to subsidiaries "that already had investment-grade ratings and pre-approved ESG lender lines," which are exactly the units most able to secure cheaper financing in a correction. Because excluded, weaker subsidiaries would face different spreads and access constraints, the 120 bps reduction observed in the pilot does not justify a company-wide intervention effect.
gold_rationale: The pilot’s participants were chosen based on financing capacity (investment-grade + ESG lender access). That same capacity directly influences funding costs during a market correction, so the observed 120 bps drop likely reflects who was included rather than the causal effect for all subsidiaries.

scenario: In H1 2023, during a sector rotation after an interest rate decision, Pharma Inc piloted an interest-rate hedge: buying payer swaptions embedded in a callable note tied to its bond issuance. The pilot was run only on desks allowed to trade with the FDA-risk “clean” BioTech Start collateral package and with the tightest risk limits. Those desks reported 12% lower weekly P&L volatility versus peers over 8 weeks.
claim: Rolling out the payer-swaption callable-note hedge across all of Pharma Inc’s derivatives desks causes a 12% reduction in weekly P&L volatility.
label: NO

X.name: Roll out the payer-swaption callable-note hedge to a derivatives desk

Y.name: Weekly P&L volatility of the desk

Z: Desk eligibility for the pilot (FDA-risk “clean” collateral package access and tight risk-limit approval)

causal_structure: Z (pilot eligibility) influences inclusion in treatment (X) and is associated with lower baseline risk-taking and better hedging execution, which affects Y; estimating X→Y on the selected Z=eligible desks does not identify the effect for all desks.
key_insight: An intervention tested only on specially approved/low-risk desks won’t reliably predict the effect on the whole organization.
wise_refusal: NO. The claim relies on a selected, non-representative pilot sample (selection bias). The scenario states the pilot was run “only on desks allowed to trade with the FDA-risk ‘clean’ BioTech Start collateral package and with the tightest risk limits,” which are precisely the kinds of constraints that also affect “weekly P&L volatility.” Because the treated desks differ systematically from the desks excluded from the pilot, the 12% reduction cannot be attributed to the hedge for the general population of all desks.
gold_rationale: The observed volatility reduction comes from a pilot run on desks selected for special eligibility (clean collateral access and tight risk limits). Those selection criteria plausibly correlate with the outcome (lower volatility) independent of the hedge itself, so the pilot estimate can’t be generalized to all derivatives desks.

scenario: In H2 2023, after a surprise US CPI print spiked crypto volatility, a Crypto Exchange launched an “auto-stable” routing feature that automatically sends eligible users’ stablecoin deposits into a partnered DeFi Protocol for yield. The pilot was run only on accounts in the exchange’s “Pro” tier with KYC, $50k+ balances, and at least 30 trades/month. Those users showed a 22% increase in stablecoin deposits over 8 weeks versus their own prior baseline.
claim: Rolling out the exchange’s auto-stable routing feature to all users causes stablecoin deposits on the exchange to increase by about 22%.
label: NO

X.name: Auto-stable routing feature enabled for an account (exchange routes stablecoin deposits into partnered DeFi protocol yield)

Y.name: Change in stablecoin deposits on the exchange over the next 8 weeks

Z: Eligibility/selection into the pilot (Pro-tier, KYC completed, $50k+ balance, 30+ trades/month / high-engagement account status)

causal_structure: Z (high-engagement/wealthy Pro accounts) influences both receiving the intervention (X) and the outcome (Y: deposit growth); estimating X→Y within selected Z does not identify the effect in the full user population.
key_insight: An intervention tested only on highly engaged, high-balance users can’t be assumed to work the same for everyone.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a selection-bias problem: the intervention was evaluated on a non-representative sample whose selection is related to the outcome. The scenario says the pilot was run only on "accounts in the exchange’s 'Pro' tier with KYC, $50k+ balances, and at least 30 trades/month," and those traits are plausibly linked to higher stablecoin funding during volatile periods. Because many users (non-Pro, low-balance, low-activity, non-KYC) were excluded, the 22% increase cannot be claimed as the causal effect of rolling out the feature to all users.
gold_rationale: The pilot’s effect is measured on a non-representative subset: Pro-tier, KYC’d, high-balance, high-frequency traders. Those characteristics correlate with propensity to add stablecoin capital—especially after volatile macro news—so the observed deposit increase may reflect who was studied rather than what the feature caused. Generalizing the pilot result to the entire exchange user base commits selection bias.

scenario: In 2022, after geopolitical tensions spiked EUR/USD volatility, an institutional fund hired a new CIO and piloted “auto-hedge” FX forwards for 40 retail investors routed through a market maker. Only accounts with >$250k and a 3-year record (kept through the volatility) were invited. From 2022–2023, this group’s portfolios showed 2.1% lower FX-related drawdowns than similar unhedged accounts.
claim: Rolling out the auto-hedge FX forward program causes retail investors to experience 2.1% lower FX-related drawdowns.
label: NO

X.name: Auto-hedge FX forward program enabled via the market maker

Y.name: FX-related portfolio drawdown over 2022–2023

Z: Invitation eligibility (>$250k and survived 3 years of prior volatility / high sophistication)

causal_structure: Z influences both receiving the intervention X (only eligible investors are treated) and the outcome Y (eligible investors tend to manage risk better), so the observed X–Y difference in the pilot is biased and may not generalize to all retail investors.
key_insight: An intervention tested only on “safe” or sophisticated accounts can’t be assumed to work the same for the broader retail population.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a selection-bias trap: the intervention effect is estimated on a non-representative sample. The scenario says, "Only accounts with >$250k and a 3-year record (kept through the volatility) were invited." Those excluded—smaller, newer, or less risk-managed retail accounts—are precisely the ones likely to have different drawdown behavior and hedging frictions (margin, costs, execution). Because eligibility correlates with drawdowns, the pilot result cannot be generalized to all retail investors.
gold_rationale: The pilot’s treated group is not representative: participation required high balances and having already endured prior volatility. Those traits are correlated with drawdown outcomes regardless of hedging. Therefore, the 2.1% improvement observed in the selected pilot cannot justify a causal claim about rolling out the program to all retail investors.

scenario: After an industry disruption hit regional banks, the Treasury and Central Bank evaluated a new “dividend-announcement liquidity backstop” meant to stabilize fixed-income markets. Over the last 12 months they activated it only for primary dealers that requested access and met heightened collateral and reporting standards. In that selected group, bid–ask spreads in on-the-run Treasuries tightened by 6 bps within two weeks of dividend announcements.
claim: Activating the dividend-announcement liquidity backstop causes Treasury bid–ask spreads to tighten by about 6 bps across the entire bond market.
label: NO

X.name: Activation of the Central Bank/Treasury dividend-announcement liquidity backstop

Y.name: Change in Treasury bond-market bid–ask spreads (liquidity)

Z: Eligibility/self-selection into the pilot (primary dealer status, collateral quality, and willingness to request access)

causal_structure: Z influences both receiving the intervention (X) and market liquidity outcomes (Y); the observed X–Y effect is estimated only among selected eligible/requesting dealers, so it need not equal the effect in the full bond market.
key_insight: An intervention tested only on a selected, higher-quality subset can’t be assumed to produce the same effect market-wide.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a selection-bias trap: the effect was measured on a non-representative group that is systematically different from the broader bond market. The scenario says the program was activated “only for primary dealers that requested access and met heightened collateral and reporting standards.” Those excluded (non-primary dealers, weaker collateral firms, or those unwilling to opt in) likely have worse liquidity conditions, so the 6 bps tightening observed in the selected group does not justify claiming the same tightening “across the entire bond market.”
gold_rationale: The scenario reports a liquidity improvement after the backstop was activated, but activation occurred only among dealers who both met strict requirements and chose to request access. Those features (strong balance sheets, better collateral, better risk systems) are directly related to tighter spreads, especially during event-driven volatility like dividend announcements. The estimated effect from this non-representative sample may not generalize to the broader bond market.

scenario: In Q1 2024, during high market volatility, TechCorp executed a 10-for-1 stock split. A private equity secondaries desk at RetailGiant “tested” an intervention: automatically increasing allocation to split-announcement trades, but only in accounts tagged as “high-liquidity, low-redemption” (large institutional mandates). In that selected subset, the split-trade overlay beat the Market Index by 2.8% over four weeks. RetailGiant proposed rolling it out to all client accounts.
claim: Automatically increasing allocation to TechCorp stock-split announcement trades causes all RetailGiant client accounts to outperform the Market Index by about 2.8% over the next four weeks.
label: NO

X.name: Split-trade overlay: automatic increase in allocation to TechCorp around the stock split announcement

Y.name: Four-week excess return vs the Market Index

Z: Account eligibility tag (high-liquidity, low-redemption institutional mandates vs other accounts)

causal_structure: Z influences inclusion in the test and also affects Y (via trading costs, ability to hold through volatility, and forced-selling risk). X is evaluated only among Z=eligible accounts, so the estimated effect of X on Y does not generalize to all accounts.
key_insight: An intervention’s backtest on a cherry-picked client subset doesn’t identify its effect for the full client base.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a selection-bias trap: the intervention was evaluated on a non-representative subset whose characteristics also affect performance. The scenario says the overlay was tested "only in accounts tagged as 'high-liquidity, low-redemption' (large institutional mandates)." Those excluded accounts (smaller, less liquid, higher-redemption) can face higher trading costs and forced selling during volatility, which changes excess returns. So the 2.8% estimate from the selected group does not justify the causal claim for all RetailGiant client accounts.
gold_rationale: The intervention effect is inferred from a non-representative subset: accounts chosen for high liquidity and low redemption risk. Those characteristics directly relate to realized excess returns during volatile periods (through lower transaction costs and fewer forced liquidations). Because the test excludes accounts with worse execution and higher flow-driven selling, the observed 2.8% excess return cannot be assumed to hold for the broader client population.

scenario: In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty and an acquisition offer, Alpha Fund asked Beta Securities to pilot a new compliance “fast-track” review that pre-clears trades tied to the deal. Beta tested it only on its top-ranked senior compliance officers who volunteered for overtime and historically had the fewest regulatory exceptions. Over 8 weeks, desks using the fast-track saw a 30% drop in flagged-trade incidents versus prior weeks.
claim: Rolling out the compliance fast-track review across all Beta Securities compliance teams causes a 30% reduction in flagged-trade incidents during acquisition-offer periods.
label: NO

X.name: Compliance fast-track pre-clearance review rollout

Y.name: Flagged-trade incident rate during acquisition-offer periods

Z: Senior/elite compliance officer participation (volunteer overtime; historically low exception rates)

causal_structure: Z influences both adoption in the pilot (X measured on a selected subset) and the outcome Y; the observed X–Y association is estimated within a non-representative group, so it need not equal the effect of X in the full compliance organization.
key_insight: An intervention tested only on unusually capable/low-risk participants can’t be assumed to have the same effect when applied to everyone.
wise_refusal: NO. The claim relies on a selected pilot sample, so the estimated intervention effect may not generalize. The scenario says Beta tested it "only on its top-ranked senior compliance officers who volunteered for overtime and historically had the fewest regulatory exceptions." Those excluded (e.g., junior teams, higher-exception desks, other shifts/regions) likely have different baseline error rates and implementation quality, so rolling out the fast-track to everyone would not necessarily produce the same 30% reduction in flagged-trade incidents.
gold_rationale: The pilot’s treated group was not representative: it used volunteer senior officers with historically fewer exceptions. That selection mechanism is correlated with the outcome (flagged incidents), so the observed 30% drop could reflect who was selected rather than what the fast-track causes. Generalizing to all teams (including less experienced staff and different shifts/regions) is therefore unjustified.

scenario: In Q3 2024, after a major policy shift clarified custody rules for tokenized securities, Bank ABC piloted a “guaranteed allocation” digital-asset IPO access program with Insurance Corp. Credit Agency helped select only clients with top-tier credit scores and high verified liquidity. Those invited received earlier allocations and tighter spreads; their average first-week IPO return beat the standard book by 6%. Bank ABC proposed rolling it out to all wealth clients for future IPOs.
claim: Rolling out Bank ABC’s guaranteed-allocation digital-asset IPO access program to all wealth clients causes a 6% higher first-week IPO return.
label: NO

X.name: Guaranteed-allocation digital-asset IPO access program rollout

Y.name: First-week IPO return relative to the standard allocation book

Z: Client selection criteria (top-tier credit score and high verified liquidity)

causal_structure: Z (creditworthiness/liquidity) influences selection into X and also directly influences Y (ability to hold through volatility, lower forced selling, better execution); the observed uplift in Y among treated clients mixes X’s effect with Z-driven differences.
key_insight: An intervention tested only on hand-picked high-quality clients won’t automatically produce the same effect for the full client base.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a selection-bias trap: the intervention effect was estimated on a non-representative pilot. The scenario says, "Credit Agency helped select only clients with top-tier credit scores and high verified liquidity." Those same characteristics can improve IPO outcomes (e.g., less forced selling and better execution), so the 6% outperformance may reflect who was chosen, not what the program would do for the broader client base that was excluded.
gold_rationale: The pilot’s treated group was not representative: Credit Agency screened in only clients with strong credit and liquidity, traits that are plausibly linked to IPO trading performance (ability to avoid forced sales, access to better execution, higher risk tolerance). Estimating the intervention’s effect on this selected subgroup does not justify a claim about all wealth clients.

scenario: In Q4 2024, during a bull market, an ESG-focused credit fund offered an “intervention” to portfolio companies: a discounted sustainability-linked loan (SLL) to fund capex, tested only on issuers already rated AA/AAA on ESG risk.
