Energy Co and Green Power accepted; Oil Major was excluded because it had just filed for bankruptcy and couldn’t access new credit. The AA/AAA group’s bond spreads tightened 45 bps vs peers.
claim: Offering the discounted sustainability-linked loan causes all energy-sector issuers’ bond spreads to tighten by about 45 bps in Q4 2024.
label: NO

X.name: Offering a discounted sustainability-linked loan (SLL) to the issuer

Y.name: Issuer bond-spread tightening (bps) over Q4 2024

Z: Eligibility/selection into the SLL pilot (AA/AAA ESG risk rating and ability to access new credit; bankruptcy filing excludes issuers)

causal_structure: Z (eligibility/credit access) influences receiving X and also directly affects Y (spread tightening); the observed effect of X on Y in the selected AA/AAA, non-bankrupt sample does not identify the effect for the full population including distressed/bankrupt issuers.
key_insight: An intervention’s effect estimated on a cherry-picked, credit-eligible subset won’t generalize to firms that were excluded (especially distressed/bankrupt ones).
wise_refusal: NO. This is a selection-bias trap: the intervention was evaluated on a non-representative, credit-eligible subset rather than the full energy sector. The scenario says the SLL was “tested only on issuers already rated AA/AAA on ESG risk” and that “Oil Major was excluded because it had just filed for bankruptcy and couldn’t access new credit.” Eligibility and bankruptcy/credit access are linked to spread tightening in a bull market, so the 45 bps improvement for the selected group doesn’t justify claiming the same effect for all issuers.
gold_rationale: The pilot’s treated group is defined by eligibility (high ESG rating and ability to borrow), while a key excluded entity (Oil Major) filed for bankruptcy and therefore cannot be treated. Creditworthiness/distress strongly predicts spread moves in a bull market, so the observed tightening conflates treatment with selection, invalidating a population-wide causal claim.

scenario: In H1 2023, during a sector rotation out of high-multiple biotech, a desk reviewed trades where it “bought Pharma Inc and BioTech Start at the close right after their earnings announcement” and held until the first FDA decision headline. The memo reports a +18% average return across the positions that were still held through the FDA headline, noting several trades were closed early after sharp drawdowns and excluded as “not completed.”
claim: Buying Pharma Inc and BioTech Start right after their earnings announcements and holding until the first FDA decision headline causes positive abnormal returns during sector rotations.
label: NO

X.name: Post-earnings buy-and-hold-until-FDA strategy on Pharma Inc and BioTech Start

Y.name: Abnormal return from entry (post-earnings close) to exit (first FDA headline)

Z: Attrition from the strategy (positions stopped out/closed early after drawdowns and excluded from analysis)

causal_structure: X is assigned, but analysis conditions on Z=survived-to-FDA; survival is influenced by interim price moves and risk controls that are also related to Y, so estimating E[Y|X,Z=survive] overstates the effect of X on Y.
key_insight: A strategy can look profitable if you only average returns from trades that survive long enough to be measured.
wise_refusal: NO. The intervention effect is not justified because the analysis only measures outcomes on survivors/completers. The scenario says the return was computed on positions “that were still held through the FDA headline,” while “several trades were closed early after sharp drawdowns and excluded as ‘not completed.’” Those dropouts are part of what would happen under the intervention; excluding them biases the estimate upward and overstates profitability.
gold_rationale: The reported +18% average is calculated only for positions that remained open until the FDA headline. Trades that were stopped out or closed early after drawdowns are explicitly excluded, creating a survivorship filter that mechanically removes many losing paths and inflates the apparent intervention effect of the buy-and-hold strategy.

scenario: In H2 2023, right after a surprise CPI print, a major Crypto Exchange announced a merger with a DeFi Protocol that runs a USD stablecoin. The exchange rolled out an “auto-hedge” trading strategy for market makers during the announcement week. In its report, it calculated P&L only for accounts that kept the strategy enabled all 5 days; 38% disabled it after large intraday drawdowns.
claim: Rolling out the auto-hedge trading strategy causes market makers to earn higher P&L during merger-announcement volatility.
label: NO

X.name: Enabling the exchange’s auto-hedge strategy for market making during the merger-announcement week

Y.name: Market maker P&L over the 5-day announcement window

Z: Attrition/disablement of the strategy after drawdowns (only completers are analyzed)

causal_structure: X influences early drawdowns, which influence Z (staying enabled). Conditioning on Z=completed selects accounts with better outcomes, biasing the estimated effect of X on Y upward.
key_insight: A strategy can look profitable when you only average results from the accounts that survived long enough to be measured.
wise_refusal: NO. The reasoning conditions on survivors/completers, creating a biased estimate. The scenario says the exchange “calculated P&L only for accounts that kept the strategy enabled all 5 days” and that “38% disabled it after large intraday drawdowns.” Those dropouts likely had worse outcomes; excluding them inflates the average and you can’t conclude the strategy causes higher P&L without accounting for what happened to the accounts that disabled it.
gold_rationale: The exchange’s effectiveness claim is based on P&L calculated only for accounts that kept the strategy on for the full window. Accounts that turned it off after losses are excluded, so the reported average is mechanically tilted toward survivors who happened to do well, overstating the intervention’s benefit.

scenario: In 2022, after a regulatory change responding to geopolitical tensions raised margin requirements on index options, a Retail Investor copied an Institutional Fund’s “dynamic put-spread hedge” executed via a Market Maker. The fund’s report evaluated only accounts that kept the hedge on through all 12 monthly rolls in 2022–2023. Among these “completers,” max drawdown averaged -6% versus -14% unhedged, and the fund touted the hedge as effective.
claim: Implementing the dynamic put-spread hedging program causes lower maximum drawdowns for investors during 2022–2023.
label: NO

X.name: Adopting the dynamic put-spread hedge and rolling it monthly

Y.name: Portfolio maximum drawdown over 2022–2023

Z: Attrition/selection into the analyzed sample (accounts that completed all 12 hedge rolls; dropouts liquidated or stopped after margin calls/slippage)

causal_structure: X affects the chance of staying in the program (Z); conditioning on Z (only completers) selects accounts with better liquidity/discipline and better outcomes Y, inflating the apparent effect of X on Y.
key_insight: A hedge’s “performance” computed only on accounts that survived all rolls can’t justify the intervention’s causal benefit.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed because it evaluates the hedge only on survivors/completers, not everyone who adopted it. The scenario says the report "evaluated only accounts that kept the hedge on through all 12 monthly rolls" and reports results "among these 'completers'." If investors who stopped (e.g., after margin calls, bad fills, or forced unwinds) are excluded, the observed -6% drawdown reflects a selected subset and cannot justify the claim that doing the hedge causes lower drawdowns for investors in general. What happened to those who dropped out or failed?
gold_rationale: The fund’s comparison uses only investors who completed all monthly hedge rolls, excluding those who discontinued due to increased margin requirements, slippage, or losses. This selection on survivors biases the estimated intervention effect upward, making the hedge look more protective than it is for a typical investor.

scenario: Following an industry disruption and a sharp market correction over the last 12 months, the Central Bank launched a bond-buyback facility and the Treasury expanded issuance to stabilize funding. An internal memo reviewed only primary dealers that stayed active through all 12 monthly operations; among these “completers,” average bid-ask spreads in the bond market tightened from 22 bps to 12 bps. Dealers that stopped participating after early losses or margin calls were excluded.
claim: Launching the Central Bank’s bond-buyback facility causes tighter bond-market liquidity spreads.
label: NO

X.name: Central Bank bond-buyback facility (monthly operations over 12 months)

Y.name: Bond-market liquidity (bid-ask spread tightening)

Z: Dealer survival/continued participation through all 12 operations (dropout/exit after losses or margin calls)

causal_structure: X is evaluated only among Z=1 (dealers who remain active). Z is affected by stress and losses that also affect Y, so conditioning on Z selects survivors with better liquidity outcomes, overstating X→Y.
key_insight: If you only measure outcomes for those who stayed in, the intervention will look better than it really is.
wise_refusal: NO. The reasoning suffers from survivorship/attrition bias: it evaluates the buyback facility only among entities that survived and kept participating. The scenario explicitly says the memo reviewed “only primary dealers that stayed active through all 12 monthly operations” and that “dealers that stopped participating after early losses or margin calls were excluded.” Those dropouts are plausibly the ones with worse liquidity and stress, so ignoring them overstates the facility’s effect. The key missing question is: what happened to those who dropped out or failed?
gold_rationale: The memo infers an intervention effect from a sample restricted to dealers who completed all monthly operations. Excluding dealers that exited after losses/margin calls removes likely bad-liquidity episodes, mechanically making the remaining group’s spreads look improved even if the facility’s true average effect is smaller or negative.

scenario: In Q1 2024, during high volatility around an interest rate decision, TechCorp’s treasury desk rolled a structured note on the Market Index to “stabilize funding costs.” RetailGiant reviewed only the notes that reached maturity without a barrier breach and saw an average +6% payoff versus holding cash. Notes that knocked out early or were forcibly unwound after margin calls were excluded from the summary.
claim: Implementing TechCorp’s Market Index structured-note hedge causes a positive payoff through the rate-decision volatility window.
label: NO

X.name: Implementing the Market Index structured-note hedge (buying the note program)

Y.name: Net payoff/return over the Q1 2024 rate-decision window

Z: Survival/completion status of the note position (reaches maturity without knockout/unwind)
Early knockout/barrier breach and forced unwind due to margin calls

causal_structure: X influences whether positions survive to maturity (Z); the analysis conditions on Z=survived, and survival is also related to Y, inflating the observed average payoff among completers.
key_insight: Averaging returns only for positions that made it to maturity overstates the intervention’s effect.
wise_refusal: NO. This intervention-effect claim is based on survivorship among positions. The scenario says RetailGiant "reviewed only the notes that reached maturity without a barrier breach" and that notes "knocked out early or were forcibly unwound after margin calls were excluded." Those dropouts/failures likely had worse (or at least different) payoffs, so using only completers biases the average upward. Without accounting for the excluded positions, you can’t justify that implementing the note hedge causes a positive payoff.
gold_rationale: The reported +6% payoff is computed only on structured notes that survived to maturity. Positions that failed—knocked out early or forcibly unwound after margin calls—are excluded, so the estimate is conditioned on “survival,” which is correlated with better outcomes during volatile rate-decision periods.

scenario: In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty, Alpha Fund launched a “CalmTrade” playbook via Beta Securities for Hedge Fund X’s discretionary traders during a volatile product launch week. Of 40 traders enrolled, 16 stopped using it after two losing days and were removed from the review. Alpha Fund reported that the 24 traders who kept using CalmTrade finished the quarter up +6.2% versus their prior average of +1.1%, and presented this as evidence the playbook works.
claim: Implementing Alpha Fund’s CalmTrade playbook causes Hedge Fund X traders to achieve higher Q2 2024 returns.
label: NO

X.name: Use of the CalmTrade playbook during Q2 2024 (enrolled and follows it)

Y.name: Trader’s Q2 2024 trading return (%)

Z: Attrition/completion status (stopped using after early losses vs continued)
Early-week P&L during the product launch volatility

causal_structure: X is evaluated only among traders who remain in the program; early losses influence dropout (Z), and Z is related to Y, so conditioning on completion creates a biased estimate of X→Y.
key_insight: A “completers-only” performance lift can be entirely driven by who stayed, not by the intervention’s effect.
wise_refusal: NO. This inference suffers from survivorship/attrition bias: the outcome is evaluated only on those who stayed in the intervention. The scenario says, "16 stopped using it after two losing days and were removed from the review" and then reports results for "the 24 traders who kept using CalmTrade." Excluding the dropouts—who left precisely after losses—can mechanically raise the average return of the remaining group, so the claim that the playbook causes higher Q2 returns is not justified without accounting for the missing outcomes.
gold_rationale: The reported +6.2% is calculated only for the 24 traders who continued using CalmTrade, while 16 traders who quit after early losses are excluded. Because quitting is linked to poor early performance, the analysis conditions on survivors and inflates the apparent benefit of the intervention.

scenario: In Q3 2024, after a major policy shift widened FX swings, Bank ABC replaced its FX head and mandated a new “dynamic hedging” playbook for corporate clients. Insurance Corp reviewed only the 120 client accounts that stayed on the program through quarter-end and reported their average USD/EUR hedging P&L improved by +2.1%. Accounts that exited mid-quarter after margin calls or mandate breaches were excluded; Credit Agency only rated the remaining accounts.
claim: Mandating Bank ABC’s dynamic hedging playbook after the executive change causes corporate clients to earn higher USD/EUR hedging profits.
label: NO

X.name: Mandate adoption of Bank ABC’s dynamic hedging playbook (post-executive change)

Y.name: Client USD/EUR hedging profit (P&L improvement) by quarter-end

Z: Program completion/survival to quarter-end (not exiting after margin calls/mandate breaches)

causal_structure: X is evaluated only among Z=1 (accounts that survive/complete). X can increase both the chance of dropping out (via margin calls) and P&L among survivors; conditioning on Z biases the estimated effect on Y upward.
key_insight: A strategy can look profitable when you only measure the accounts that made it to the end.
wise_refusal: NO. The causal claim relies on a survivorship-only sample. The scenario states Insurance Corp reviewed "only the 120 client accounts that stayed on the program through quarter-end" and that accounts that "exited mid-quarter after margin calls or mandate breaches were excluded." If the intervention pushes some clients into losses or margin calls leading them to drop out, omitting them overstates the playbook’s effectiveness. The key missing piece is: what happened to those who dropped out or failed?
gold_rationale: The reported improvement is computed only on accounts that completed the program through quarter-end, while accounts that failed under the strategy (exited after margin calls or breaches) are excluded. This selective observation inflates apparent effectiveness and does not justify a causal claim about what would happen if the playbook were mandated for all clients.

scenario: In Q4 2024’s bull market, a credit hedge fund bought bonds only after a company’s dividend announcement, focusing on Energy Co, Green Power, and Oil Major. It reports that among the positions it held through the next 30 days (i.e., trades not stopped out or sold early), the average total return was +4.2%. The PM proposes scaling the “buy-after-dividend” rule because the completed holds performed well.
claim: Implementing the strategy of buying the issuers’ bonds immediately after their dividend announcement causes positive 30-day bond returns.
label: NO

X.name: Buy issuer bonds immediately after the Q4 2024 dividend announcement (strategy rule)

Y.name: 30-day total return on the bond position

Z: Positions that were stopped out, sold early, or defaulted/downgraded before day 30 (excluded from the reported average)

causal_structure: X is applied to all intended trades, but conditioning the performance calculation on Z=survived-to-day-30 selects a non-representative subset; survival is influenced by adverse price moves/credit events that also determine Y, inflating the apparent effect of X on Y.
key_insight: A strategy can look profitable if you only measure returns on positions that survived long enough to be counted.
wise_refusal: NO. The causal claim relies on survivorship/attrition in the measurement. The scenario says results are computed only for positions it "held through the next 30 days (i.e., trades not stopped out or sold early)." That excludes the trades that failed to make it to the 30-day window, which are precisely the ones likely to have poor returns due to spread widening, downgrades, or liquidity-driven exits. Without knowing what happened to those dropped positions, you can’t justify that doing X causes positive 30-day returns; the effect is likely overstated.
gold_rationale: The fund reports performance only for positions it “held through the next 30 days,” excluding trades that exited early or blew up. Those excluded trades are likely the losers (e.g., widened spreads after a negative credit development), so the observed average return overstates what the intervention (the buy-after-dividend rule) would produce across all trades.

scenario: In H1 2023, during a sector rotation out of biotech, Pharma Inc announced a 2-for-1 stock split and pitched it as a liquidity-boosting intervention. An internal note highlighted that among retail accounts that “held through the split and stayed active for 60 days,” the average post-split return was +18%. The note excluded accounts that sold immediately after the split or stopped trading after an FDA headline shocked the sector.
claim: Executing the 2-for-1 stock split causes investors to earn higher 60-day returns in Pharma Inc shares.
label: NO

X.name: Pharma Inc executes a 2-for-1 stock split in H1 2023

Y.name: Investor 60-day post-split return in Pharma Inc

Z: Attrition/selection into the analyzed sample (only accounts that held through the split and remained active for 60 days; excludes immediate sellers/inactive accounts after FDA-driven volatility)

causal_structure: X occurs, but analysis conditions on Z (surviving/remaining active and holding), which is influenced by post-split price moves and FDA news; conditioning on Z selects winners and inflates the apparent X→Y effect.
key_insight: A split can’t be credited for returns when you only measure outcomes for the investors who stayed long enough to be counted.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a survivorship/attrition problem: the performance is calculated only for investors who remained in the sample long enough to be measured. The scenario explicitly restricts the analysis to “retail accounts that ‘held through the split and stayed active for 60 days,’” and it “excluded accounts that sold immediately after the split or stopped trading after an FDA headline.” If the dropouts/immediate sellers had different (likely worse) returns, the reported +18% is biased upward, so you can’t justify that the split caused higher 60-day returns without accounting for those who left.
gold_rationale: The note estimates the split’s benefit using only “accounts that held through the split and stayed active for 60 days,” excluding those who exited or dropped out after an FDA-related shock. Those excluded investors plausibly had worse outcomes (e.g., sold into losses or avoided further volatility), so the +18% average overstates the intervention’s effect.

scenario: In H2 2023, after an unexpected CPI print triggered volatility, a Crypto Exchange rolled out a “rapid compliance hardening” package for DeFi Protocol clients seeking an acquisition offer from a regulated buyer. The exchange reported that among the 18 protocols that completed the 10‑week package, 14 received acquisition offers and average offer premiums were +22%. The exchange excluded 27 protocols that started but didn’t finish due to delistings, liquidity freezes, or legal hold notices.
claim: Implementing the Crypto Exchange’s rapid compliance hardening package causes DeFi protocols to receive higher-premium acquisition offers.
label: NO

X.name: Enrollment in and completion of the rapid compliance hardening package

Y.name: Acquisition offer outcome (receipt and premium size)

Z: Attrition during the package (dropout due to delisting, liquidity freeze, or legal hold)

causal_structure: X influences Z (who completes), and Z is strongly related to Y; the reported X→Y association is computed only among Z=completed, overstating the intervention effect.
key_insight: If you only measure outcomes on the protocols that survive the process, you’ll overestimate the benefit of the intervention.
wise_refusal: NO. This is survivorship bias: the effectiveness is calculated only on the protocols that made it to the end, not on everyone who received the intervention. The scenario says, “among the 18 protocols that completed the 10‑week package…” and that it “excluded 27 protocols that started but didn’t finish due to delistings, liquidity freezes, or legal hold notices.” Those dropouts are exactly the cases that likely would have had fewer or worse acquisition offers, so conditioning on completion inflates the apparent impact. What happened to those who dropped out or failed is missing, so the causal claim isn’t justified.
gold_rationale: The exchange reports success rates and premiums only for protocols that completed the 10-week compliance package, explicitly excluding those that dropped out due to adverse events (delistings, liquidity freezes, legal holds). Those exclusions are likely correlated with poorer acquisition prospects, so the observed high offer rate among completers cannot justify a causal intervention claim.

scenario: In 2022–2023, amid geopolitical tensions, a fintech firm launched a digital-asset trading platform via an IPO. A market maker reviewed only days when both retail investors placed heavy buy orders and an institutional fund also traded the IPO (their “two-sided liquidity days”). Within that subset, higher retail buy volume coincided with worse end-of-day IPO returns, so they recommended throttling retail order flow to boost returns.
claim: Throttling retail investor buy order flow causes the IPO’s end-of-day return to increase.
label: NO

X.name: Retail investor buy-order volume in the IPO-linked token/stock

Y.name: End-of-day IPO return (close-to-open)

Z: Two-sided liquidity day (both heavy retail activity AND institutional fund participation / market-maker quoting enabled)

causal_structure: X -> Z <- Y, where Z is the selected sample (two-sided liquidity days). Conditioning on Z induces a spurious X–Y association that need not exist overall.
key_insight: If you only analyze periods selected by a variable caused by both demand and returns, you can manufacture a fake causal effect.
wise_refusal: NO. This is collider bias from conditioning on a common effect. The analysis explicitly restricts to a selected subset: "reviewed only days when both retail investors placed heavy buy orders and an institutional fund also traded the IPO (their 'two-sided liquidity days')." That selection variable is influenced by both retail flow (X helps make a day qualify) and the day’s return/price action (Y influences institutional participation and quoting), so conditioning on it can create a spurious negative X–Y correlation. Therefore, throttling retail flow is not justified as a causal way to increase returns.
gold_rationale: Z (“two-sided liquidity day”) is a common effect of both retail flow (X increases the chance a day qualifies) and strong/volatile returns (Y attracts institutional participation and quoting). By restricting analysis to Z=1, the market maker opens a non-causal path between X and Y, producing an apparent negative relationship that disappears when not conditioning on Z.

scenario: Over the last 12 months, after an industry disruption triggered a high-profile bankruptcy filing by a green infrastructure developer, the Central Bank and Treasury monitored ESG-labeled corporate bonds. An analyst studied only bonds that were added to the Central Bank’s “eligible-to-purchase” list, which requires both high ESG scores and sufficient secondary-market liquidity. Within this eligible list, bonds with tighter Treasury-spread (more “green tightening”) later showed worse total returns in the Bond Market.
claim: Pushing ESG bond spreads tighter causes subsequent ESG bond total returns to fall.
label: NO

X.name: degree of ESG spread tightening versus Treasuries (bps)

Y.name: subsequent 3-month total return of the bond

Z: Central Bank 'eligible-to-purchase' list inclusion (requires high ESG score and sufficient liquidity)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y: bonds are included on the eligibility list partly because they experienced ESG-driven spread tightening (X) and partly because strong expected/realized performance and liquidity support total returns (Y); conditioning on Z induces a spurious X–Y association.
key_insight: If you only analyze assets that pass a screen driven by both the exposure and the outcome, you can manufacture a false causal effect.
wise_refusal: NO. This conclusion relies on conditioning on a collider (selection effect). The scenario says the analyst studied only bonds “added to the Central Bank’s ‘eligible-to-purchase’ list, which requires both high ESG scores and sufficient secondary-market liquidity.” That eligibility screen is influenced by factors tied to spread tightening (X) and by liquidity/quality/performance forces that also affect subsequent total returns (Y). By restricting to eligible bonds (conditioning on Z), the analysis can create a spurious negative X–Y relationship that would not hold in the broader bond market, so the intervention claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The analyst restricted the sample to bonds on the Central Bank’s purchase-eligibility list. That list is influenced by both the exposure (ESG-driven spread tightening makes bonds more likely to qualify/attract eligibility scrutiny) and outcome-related factors (liquidity and performance/quality signals that also drive subsequent returns). Conditioning on this common effect (Z) can induce a misleading negative relationship between X and Y even if tightening does not causally reduce returns.

scenario: In Q1 2024, during high market volatility after TechCorp’s earnings announcement, a quant desk reviewed only “index-eligible movers”: stocks that both (a) had unusually high options-implied volatility on the day (X) and (b) were heavily traded by macro funds tracking the Market Index (Y). Within this filtered set, higher implied vol was linked to lower next-day returns, so they proposed suppressing implied vol exposure to improve returns.
claim: Reducing exposure to high options-implied volatility around TechCorp’s earnings announcement causes higher next-day returns.
label: NO

X.name: Exposure to high options-implied volatility on earnings day (IV level/tilt)

Y.name: Next-day stock return (TechCorp and peers)

Z: Being classified as an “index-eligible mover” (selected subset: unusually high IV AND heavy macro-fund/Market Index-linked trading)

trap.subtype_name: Collider (conditioning on a common effect / selected sample)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y, and the analysis conditions on Z; within Z, X and Y become spuriously associated even if changing X would not change Y in the full population.
key_insight: A negative X–Y link found only after filtering on a variable influenced by both can be entirely selection-induced.
wise_refusal: NO. This is collider bias from conditioning on a common effect. The analysis restricts to a selected group: "reviewed only 'index-eligible movers': stocks that both (a) had unusually high options-implied volatility ... (X) and (b) were heavily traded by macro funds tracking the Market Index (Y)." Because this filter Z is influenced by both X and Y, conditioning on Z can create a negative X–Y correlation even if changing IV exposure would not change next-day returns in the broader set of earnings events.
gold_rationale: The desk conditions on a subset defined by Z (“index-eligible movers”), which is constructed from both high earnings-day implied volatility (X) and market-index-linked trading/next-day performance dynamics (Y). Conditioning on Z opens a non-causal path between X and Y, producing a spurious negative relationship that does not justify an intervention to reduce IV exposure.

scenario: In Q2 2024 amid economic uncertainty, Alpha Fund reviewed trades around a merger announcement and only kept "confirmed-flow" minutes—intervals where Beta Securities’ tape showed both a surge in Alpha Fund’s aggressive buy orders and a spike in Hedge Fund X’s short-covering. Within this filtered sample, minutes with heavier Alpha buying were followed by smaller upward price moves, so the PM proposed throttling Alpha’s order aggression during merger-news events.
claim: Reducing Alpha Fund’s aggressive buy-order intensity during merger-announcement windows causes larger positive short-horizon price impact.
label: NO

X.name: Alpha Fund aggressive buy-order intensity (marketable buy volume per minute)

Y.name: Short-horizon price impact after the minute (next-5-minute midprice change)

Z: “Confirmed-flow” minute flag used for analysis (selected minutes where both Alpha buy surge AND Hedge Fund X short-cover spike occurred)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (and/or drivers of Y); conditioning on Z (confirmed-flow minutes) induces a spurious association between X and Y that need not hold in all merger-announcement minutes.
key_insight: Filtering to moments defined by both high X and high Y-related activity can manufacture an X–Y relationship that vanishes without the filter.
wise_refusal: NO. This is collider bias from conditioning on a common effect. The analysis explicitly filters to “confirmed-flow” minutes—"only kept 'confirmed-flow' minutes—intervals where ... both a surge in Alpha Fund’s aggressive buy orders and a spike in Hedge Fund X’s short-covering"—which makes Z an effect of X and of another driver linked to Y. Conditioning on that filter can create a spurious (here, negative) X–Y association inside the selected sample, so you can’t conclude that throttling Alpha’s aggression would causally increase short-horizon price impact in general.
gold_rationale: The team conditioned on a sample defined by a variable Z that is triggered by both the exposure (Alpha’s buy surge) and another force tied to the outcome (Hedge Fund X short-covering, which is typically associated with upward price pressure). This selection can induce a misleading negative relationship between Alpha’s buys and subsequent price changes within the selected subset, even if changing Alpha’s aggression would not increase price impact in the full population of merger-announcement minutes.

scenario: In Q3 2024, after a major policy shift triggered a regulatory change on capital charges, Bank ABC reviewed only trades that Insurance Corp and a Credit Agency both flagged as “hedge-eligible” for reporting. Within this hedge-eligible subset, desks that increased CDS hedge notional saw worse quarterly P&L. Management proposed cutting hedge notionals to improve performance, citing the observed negative relationship in the reviewed sample.
claim: Reducing CDS hedge notional causes Bank ABC’s quarterly trading P&L to increase.
label: NO

X.name: CDS hedge notional added by the desk

Y.name: Bank ABC Q3 2024 trading P&L on the credit book

Z: “Hedge-eligible” flag (jointly approved/flagged by Insurance Corp and the Credit Agency for regulatory reporting)

trap.subtype_name: Collider (conditioning on a common effect / selection on Z)

causal_structure: X -> Z <- Y, where Z is the selection criterion; conditioning on Z induces a spurious association between X and Y even if X does not worsen P&L in the full population.
key_insight: If you only analyze cases that passed a joint approval filter influenced by both hedging intensity and outcomes, you can manufacture a fake X–Y relationship.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed because it conditions on a collider (selection on a common effect). The scenario says Bank ABC "reviewed only trades that Insurance Corp and a Credit Agency both flagged as 'hedge-eligible'" and then inferred that "desks that increased CDS hedge notional saw worse quarterly P&L." That 'hedge-eligible' flag can be influenced by both the amount of hedging (more hedging requires more approval/documentation) and by risk/performance outcomes that attract extra scrutiny. Conditioning on that common effect can create a spurious negative X–Y relationship, so you can’t conclude that cutting hedges will improve P&L.
gold_rationale: The dataset is restricted to positions “both flagged as hedge-eligible,” a common effect of (i) higher hedge notional that tends to trigger documentation/approval and (ii) portfolios with notable performance/risk outcomes that also attract scrutiny and get flagged. Conditioning on this collider creates a spurious negative correlation between hedging more (X) and P&L (Y), misleading an intervention conclusion.

scenario: In Q4 2024, after a market correction in an otherwise bull market, analysts at Oil Major reviewed only the energy firms that were approved for its “Rescue Refinancing” program. Approval required either high debt-rollover pressure (X) or strong post-correction cash-flow prospects (Y). Within approved firms (Z), they observed that higher rollover pressure correlated with better subsequent 3‑month equity performance, and proposed increasing leverage stress to boost returns.
claim: Increasing debt-rollover pressure causes higher 3-month equity returns for energy firms after the Q4 2024 correction.
label: NO

X.name: debt-rollover pressure (short-term maturities / refinancing stress)

Y.name: subsequent 3-month equity return after the correction

Z: Oil Major 'Rescue Refinancing' approval status (analyzed only approved firms)

causal_structure: X -> Z <- Y, and the analysis conditions on Z by restricting to approved firms; the induced X–Y association inside Z does not represent the population effect of intervening on X.
key_insight: Selecting on an approval flag driven by both risk and upside can manufacture a fake X–Y relationship.
wise_refusal: NO. This is collider bias from conditioning on a common effect. The scenario says they "reviewed only the energy firms that were approved for its 'Rescue Refinancing' program" and that "Approval required either high debt-rollover pressure (X) or strong post-correction cash-flow prospects (Y)." Because approval (Z) is influenced by both X and Y, restricting the analysis to approved firms creates a spurious X–Y association. That within-approved correlation cannot justify the intervention claim that increasing rollover pressure will raise returns.
gold_rationale: The analysts conditioned on Z by looking only at firms approved for “Rescue Refinancing.” But approval is caused by both high rollover pressure (need) and strong return potential (prospects). Conditioning on this common effect induces a spurious relationship between X and Y within the selected sample, making it look like more rollover pressure leads to higher returns even if it doesn’t in the broader market.

scenario: In H1 2023, during a sector rotation after an interest rate decision, a derivatives desk at Pharma Inc compared only FDA “priority-review” deals it structured with BioTech Start. Within this selected set, higher notional buying of Pharma–BioTech call spreads seemed to precede poorer subsequent P&L, so the desk proposed cutting call-spread notionals. But “priority-review” deals were initiated mainly when both FDA newsflow intensity and expected volatility were high.

label: NO

X.name: Notional size of Pharma–BioTech call-spread overlay trades

Y.name: Subsequent P&L on the structured derivatives book (next 2 weeks)

Z: FDA “priority-review” deal selection flag (desk only analyzes trades tagged priority-review)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y*: the desk conditions on Z (priority-review selection), which is more likely when both high call-spread notional appetite (driven by volatility/hedging demand) and poor eventual P&L risk are present; conditioning induces a spurious X–Y association.
key_insight: If you analyze only deals chosen because of both drivers, you can manufacture an X–Y correlation that disappears in the full population.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed intervention reasoning due to conditioning on a collider. The scenario says the desk 'compared only FDA “priority-review” deals' and that these deals 'were initiated mainly when both FDA newsflow intensity and expected volatility were high.' That means the analysis selects on Z, a deal tag that is an effect of multiple drivers tied to both position sizing (X) and eventual risk/P&L (Y). Conditioning on that common effect can create a spurious negative association, so you cannot conclude that cutting call-spread notionals will raise P&L.
gold_rationale: Z (being a “priority-review” structured deal) is a common effect of two forces: (i) higher demand to size call-spread overlays (e.g., high implied vol/hedging pressure after the rate decision) and (ii) situations with higher downside/tail risk that later harms P&L. By restricting the analysis to Z=1, the desk opens a non-causal path between X and Y, making higher notionals look harmful even if they are not in the broader set of trades.

scenario: In H2 2023, right after a surprisingly hot US CPI print, a major Crypto Exchange launched “Earn+” for a Stablecoin used inside a DeFi Protocol. The exchange’s research note analyzed only days when the Stablecoin’s on-chain volume exceeded $800M (their “high-activity launch window”). Within that subset, higher Earn+ APY coincided with lower Stablecoin price stability (larger depeg vs $1), so they proposed cutting APY to prevent depegs.
claim: Cutting the Earn+ APY during the product launch causes the Stablecoin to remain more tightly pegged to $1.
label: NO

X.name: Earn+ APY offered by the Crypto Exchange

Y.name: Stablecoin price stability (magnitude of depeg from $1)

Z: High-activity launch window (days with on-chain Stablecoin volume > $800M)

trap.subtype_name: Collider bias from conditioning on a common effect (selection on Z)

causal_structure: Earn+ APY (X) increases on-chain volume (Z); market stress after unexpected economic data also increases on-chain volume (Z) and worsens peg stability (Y). Conditioning on Z induces a spurious association between X and Y.
key_insight: If you only analyze high-volume days, you may accidentally create a fake APY–depeg relationship because volume is an effect of both incentives and stress.
wise_refusal: NO. This inference is distorted by conditioning on a collider (selection effect). The scenario says they analyzed only "days when the Stablecoin’s on-chain volume exceeded $800M (their 'high-activity launch window')." That volume threshold is an effect of both the intervention (higher "Earn+ APY" can raise volume) and macro stress "right after a surprisingly hot US CPI print" which can both raise volume and worsen depegs. By restricting to high-volume days, they can induce a spurious APY–depeg relationship that would disappear or change when you analyze all days without conditioning on volume.
gold_rationale: The analysis filters to days with very high on-chain volume, but volume is plausibly driven by both the exchange’s APY incentive (more users move funds) and by macro-driven stress (more hedging/redemptions) that also worsens depegs. Conditioning on this common effect (Z) can force an artificial negative correlation between APY and stability inside the selected sample, even if APY does not causally increase depegs in the full population of days.

scenario: During 2022–2023 geopolitical tensions, a Market Maker changed its FX desk head and introduced a tighter EUR/USD quote-spread policy. A Retail Investor blog analyzed only days when an Institutional Fund executed “high-urgency” trades through that market maker (flagged when both the spread policy was active and the fund’s internal risk alarms were triggered). Within those flagged days, tighter spreads coincided with worse execution slippage for the fund, and the blog blamed the spread tightening.
claim: Implementing a tighter EUR/USD quote-spread policy causes higher execution slippage for the Institutional Fund.
label: NO

X.name: Tighter EUR/USD quote-spread policy after the executive change

Y.name: Institutional Fund execution slippage (bps vs mid)

Z: High-urgency execution days routed to the Market Maker (selection flag)

causal_structure: X -> Z <- Y (tighter spread policy and high slippage both increase likelihood a day is labeled 'high-urgency' and included); conditioning on Z induces a spurious X–Y association.
key_insight: Filtering to a subset defined by both the policy and stress/slippage conditions can manufacture a negative relationship that isn’t causal.
wise_refusal: NO. This is collider bias from conditioning on a common effect. The blog restricts the sample to "only days when an Institutional Fund executed 'high-urgency' trades through that market maker (flagged when both the spread policy was active and the fund’s internal risk alarms were triggered)." Because that flag is more likely under the tighter-spread regime and also under conditions associated with high slippage, conditioning on it can create an artificial relationship between spread tightening and slippage. The claimed intervention effect isn’t justified without analyzing unselected days.
gold_rationale: Z (“high-urgency trades through that market maker”) is a common effect: it becomes more likely when the market maker has the tighter-spread regime active (X) and when the fund experiences stressful conditions that also drive worse slippage (Y). By analyzing only Z=1 days, the blog conditions on a collider, inducing a spurious correlation between X and Y and invalidating the intervention claim.

scenario: Over the last 12 months, after an industry disruption, the Central Bank tracked bond-market reaction days when a large bank both announced a dividend and the Treasury ran an unusually large auction. Traders labeled these as “stress-event days” and only analyzed those days. Within this selected set, higher central-bank bond buying was associated with wider credit spreads in IG corporates, leading a desk to argue buying worsens spreads.
claim: Increasing Central Bank bond purchases causes corporate credit spreads to widen.
label: NO

X.name: Central Bank bond purchase size (QE flow) on the day

Y.name: Change in IG corporate credit spreads (widening) on the day

Z: “Stress-event day” flag (day included only if both a dividend announcement and a large Treasury auction occur)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y, where Z (being labeled a stress-event day) is more likely when QE is large and when spreads are widening; conditioning on Z induces a spurious negative/positive association between X and Y that need not exist unconditionally.
key_insight: Conditioning on an event triggered by both policy response and market stress can manufacture a fake policy-to-spreads effect.
wise_refusal: NO. This is collider bias from conditioning on a common effect. The scenario says they “only analyzed those days” labeled “stress-event days,” and that label is tied to circumstances where “higher central-bank bond buying” and “wider credit spreads” are both more likely. By selecting on Z, you open the path X→Z←Y and can create an apparent relationship even if QE does not causally widen spreads in the full population of days. The intervention claim isn’t justified without an analysis that does not condition on that selection variable.
gold_rationale: The desk restricts the dataset to “stress-event days,” which are defined by a combination of a dividend announcement and a large Treasury auction and, operationally, are the days when policy desks also tend to intervene heavily and credit spreads tend to be moving sharply. Because the analysis conditions on Z (a common effect of X and Y), it opens a non-causal path between QE flow and spread widening, producing a misleading association.

scenario: In Q1 2024, amid high volatility, TechCorp executed a 10-for-1 stock split. A broker report labeled clients as “split-participants” if they held TechCorp continuously from Jan 2 until the split effective date (Mar 15), then compared Apr 1–Jun 30 returns to a “non-participant” group. The report counted Jan–Mar holding days as participant time and found participants beat the Market Index and RetailGiant by 6%.
claim: Enrolling investors into the TechCorp stock-split participation program causes higher post-split returns versus RetailGiant and the Market Index.
label: NO

X.name: Classification as TechCorp split-participant (must hold continuously until Mar 15, 2024)

Y.name: Post-split performance (Apr 1–Jun 30, 2024 total return vs Market Index and RetailGiant)

Z: Required survival/holding period Jan 2–Mar 15 (must not sell before split date)

trap.subtype_name: Immortal Time (guaranteed survival to be treated)

causal_structure: Eligibility/selection requires surviving (not selling) until Mar 15; pre-split time is misattributed to the treated group, creating an artificial advantage when comparing to those without the same survival requirement.
key_insight: If treatment status requires surviving to a future date, any apparent benefit can be a timing artifact, not an intervention effect.
wise_refusal: NO. This is immortal-time bias from the way “treated” investors are defined. The scenario says clients were labeled “split-participants” only if they “held TechCorp continuously from Jan 2 until the split effective date (Mar 15)” and the report “counted Jan–Mar holding days as participant time.” That means treated investors had to survive/hold through Mar 15 to even enter the treated group, giving them guaranteed time that the control group doesn’t have. The apparent outperformance can be an artifact of this timing/selection, not a causal effect of the split participation.
gold_rationale: The “split-participant” label is only possible for accounts that did not sell before Mar 15, creating a guaranteed period of survival/holding. The report also counts Jan–Mar days as participant time even though the split hasn’t occurred yet. This misclassified person-time makes the treated group look better, while the non-participant group includes investors who could not have qualified due to selling earlier.

scenario: In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty, Alpha Fund evaluated whether to adopt Beta Securities’ new “Enhanced Compliance Shield” after Hedge Fund X received an acquisition offer. Beta only enrolls accounts that have remained violation-free for 60 days post-offer. Alpha’s analyst compared 90-day post-offer enforcement actions, counting the first 60 days as “treated” time for enrolled accounts, and found 35% fewer actions versus non-enrolled accounts.
claim: Adopting Beta Securities’ Enhanced Compliance Shield causes fewer enforcement actions in the 90 days after an acquisition offer.
label: NO

X.name: Enrollment in Beta Securities’ Enhanced Compliance Shield program

Y.name: Enforcement actions (e.g., regulator inquiries, fines) within 90 days post-offer

Z: Immortal time: mandatory 60-day violation-free survival period after the acquisition offer to qualify for enrollment

causal_structure: Offer date starts risk time; classification as treated requires surviving violation-free for 60 days, and the analysis misclassifies that pre-enrollment window as treated person-time, creating a spurious X–Y association.
key_insight: If you must survive to be labeled treated, the apparent benefit can be guaranteed by design rather than caused by the intervention.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed intervention reasoning due to immortal time created by the eligibility rule. The scenario says, "Beta only enrolls accounts that have remained violation-free for 60 days post-offer" and the analyst "count[ed] the first 60 days as 'treated' time." That means treated accounts had to survive (stay violation-free) long enough to be labeled treated, so the observed 35% reduction can be an artifact of how time was classified rather than a true causal effect of the compliance program; the control group doesn’t get the same guaranteed survival window.
gold_rationale: The program requires accounts to be violation-free for 60 days post-offer to enroll, so enrollees necessarily avoid enforcement actions during that window. By counting those first 60 days as “treated” time, the analysis assigns guaranteed event-free time to the treatment group, inflating the apparent protective effect compared with non-enrolled accounts that do not face the same survival requirement.

scenario: After a major US stablecoin policy shift in Q3 2024, Bank ABC completed an IPO and launched an “IPO-hedge” digital-asset insurance add-on underwritten by Insurance Corp and priced using Credit Agency risk flags. Y.name: Issuer default (or failure) within 6 months after the IPO

Z: Must survive 60 days post-IPO with no missed filing to be eligible for enrollment (immortal eligibility window)

key_insight: If you must survive long enough to receive treatment, counting that pre-treatment time as treated inflates the apparent benefit.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed intervention reasoning due to immortal time created by the study design. The scenario states enrollment was “only allowed after surviving 60 days post-IPO without a missed filing,” yet the report “count[ed] firms as insured from IPO day.” That means the treated group gets 60 days of guaranteed survival time misclassified as treated time, while the non-insured group can default during those same 60 days. The apparent reduction in 6-month defaults can be an artifact of this timing, not an effect of the insurance add-on.
gold_rationale: The report labels issuers as “insured” from IPO day, but enrollment is only allowed after surviving 60 days without a missed filing. Those 60 days are guaranteed non-default time for eventual enrollees. Because the non-insured group includes firms that can default during that window, the comparison mechanically favors the insured group even if insurance has no true protective effect.

scenario: In Q4 2024’s bull market, analysts backtested an “ESG-switch” strategy: label a portfolio “treated” once it reallocates from Oil Major bonds into Green Power’s 5-year sustainability-linked note. label: NO

Y.name: Avoiding loss from Energy Co bankruptcy filing (portfolio drawdown not exceeding a threshold)

Z: Required 60-trading-day survival/solvency window before being eligible to be classified as reallocated (immortal time)

causal_structure: Eligibility requires surviving 60 days (Z) which also predicts avoiding bankruptcy-related losses (Y); pre-treatment time is counted as treated, creating an artificial association X→Y.
key_insight: If you must survive long enough to be labeled treated, the treatment group gets “free” survival time that inflates apparent benefits.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed intervention reasoning due to immortal time created by the classification rule. The scenario says the note “could only be bought after staying solvent and unhedged for 60 consecutive trading days post-issuance” and that researchers “counted the full quarter’s returns as treated” once a portfolio eventually reallocated. That means portfolios had to survive those 60 days to be labeled treated, and that pre-reallocation period was misclassified as treated time, mechanically making the treated group look safer than controls who did not have the same survival requirement.
gold_rationale: The design requires portfolios to remain solvent and unhedged for 60 trading days before they can buy (and be labeled as having bought) Green Power’s note. Yet the backtest counts the entire quarter’s returns as treated for those portfolios, meaning the first 60 days—when they could not have been treated—are incorrectly attributed to treatment. Controls do not receive the same guaranteed survival window, so the treated group’s lower bankruptcy-loss rate can be an artifact of classification timing rather than a true intervention effect.

scenario: In H1 2023, during a sector rotation into defensives, analysts backtested a “post-earnings FDA-derisk” trade: buy Pharma Inc shares if it issues an earnings announcement and then secures an FDA Type-C meeting within 45 days about a BioTech Start licensing deal. label: NO

Y.name: 30-trading-day abnormal return after the earnings announcement

wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed intervention reasoning due to an immortal-time problem. The scenario defines treatment using a future requirement: "buy Pharma Inc shares if it issues an earnings announcement and then secures an FDA Type-C meeting within 45 days" and then "label such names as 'treated' from the earnings date." That means the treated group must survive the 45-day window to even be classified as treated, and the pre-meeting period is incorrectly counted as treated time. The control group doesn’t face the same survival requirement, so the return advantage can be an artifact of classification rather than an effect of the strategy.
gold_rationale: The study defines the intervention using a post-earnings event (FDA Type-C meeting within 45 days) but counts performance from the earnings date as if already treated. To be in the treated group, Pharma Inc must “survive” long enough after earnings for the FDA-meeting criterion to be met; stocks that crater or deals that break in that window can never be treated and inflate the treated group’s apparent returns.

scenario: After unexpected US inflation data in Aug 2023, a Crypto Exchange announced a merger with a DeFi Protocol that powers a Stablecoin. label: NO

Y.name: Wallet liquidation rate during H2 2023

Z: Required 30-day post-announcement survival/solvency period to qualify for SOR access (immortal time)

key_insight: If you must survive to be labeled treated, the “benefit” can be baked into the definition of treatment.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed intervention reasoning due to immortal time created by the study design. The scenario says SOR “was only granted after a wallet stayed solvent and active for 30 consecutive days post-announcement” and that the study “counted those 30 days as treated time.” That guarantees treated wallets survive long enough to be labeled treated, so the lower liquidation rate can be an artifact of classification rather than an effect of enabling SOR; non-SOR wallets don’t get the same survival requirement.
gold_rationale: The design requires wallets to remain solvent/active for 30 days to receive SOR, yet those 30 days are counted as treated exposure time. That period is “immortal” with respect to liquidation for the treated group by construction: any wallet liquidated earlier cannot become treated. The control group does not receive the same guaranteed-survival window, inflating the apparent protective effect of SOR.

scenario: During 2022–2023, after a regulatory change on options margining introduced in response to geopolitical tensions, an institutional fund compared retail investors who “adopted a protective put hedge program” vs those who didn’t. To be labeled “hedged,” an account had to remain active for 90 days and execute at least three monthly put rolls; researchers counted returns and drawdowns from the start of the 90-day window as hedged time.

X.name: Adoption of the protective put hedge program

Y.name: Maximum drawdown of the retail investor account during 2022–2023

Z: 90-day survival/continued account activity required to be classified as hedged (immortal time window)

trap.subtype_name: Immortal Time (misclassified person-time before treatment assignment)

causal_structure: Classification into X requires surviving/remaining active for 90 days (Z). Pre-classification time is counted as treated, creating guaranteed survival time that is absent in controls, biasing the estimated effect of X on Y.
key_insight: If you must survive long enough to be called “treated,” the apparent benefit can be a labeling artifact.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed intervention reasoning due to immortal time created by the treatment definition. The scenario says: "To be labeled 'hedged,' an account had to remain active for 90 days and execute at least three monthly put rolls; researchers counted returns and drawdowns from the start of the 90-day window as hedged time." That means investors had to survive/stay active long enough to qualify as treated, and that guaranteed-survival period was misclassified as treated exposure. The lower drawdowns can be an artifact of this classification, not a true causal effect of hedging.
gold_rationale: The study defines “treated” only for accounts that remain active for 90 days and complete three monthly put rolls, but it counts performance from the start of that 90-day window as treated. This creates a period in which treated accounts must, by definition, avoid closure/blow-up to be labeled treated, inflating the apparent drawdown reduction versus controls who do not face the same survival requirement.

scenario: After an industry disruption and a sharp market correction in the last 12 months, analysts studied whether firms that adopted the Treasury–Central Bank “Liquidity Backstop Facility” had fewer bond defaults. A firm is labeled “treated” only if it successfully rolls maturing bonds and remains investment-grade for 90 days before the facility approval date. The study counts those 90 days as treated time and compares 12‑month default rates vs firms never approved.
claim: Implementing the Treasury–Central Bank Liquidity Backstop Facility for an issuer causes a lower 12-month corporate bond default rate.
label: NO

X.name: Liquidity Backstop Facility approval for an issuer

Y.name: 12-month corporate bond default occurrence

Z: 90-day survival/eligibility window prior to approval (must remain investment-grade and roll maturities)

causal_structure: Eligibility requires surviving 90 days without default; those pre-approval days are counted as exposed time, creating guaranteed non-default time in X that the control group does not share, biasing X→Y downward.
key_insight: If treatment status requires surviving to be treated, the apparent survival benefit can be a bookkeeping artifact.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed intervention reasoning due to immortal time created by the study’s treatment definition. The scenario says a firm is labeled treated only if it "remains investment-grade for 90 days before the facility approval date" and that the study "counts those 90 days as treated time." That 90-day window is guaranteed non-default time required to become treated, so the treated group’s lower 12-month default rate can be an artifact of classification rather than a true causal effect of the facility, especially since never-approved firms don’t face the same requirement.
gold_rationale: The facility can only be received after a firm demonstrates 90 days of continued survival/credit quality, and the study then misclassifies that pre-approval period as exposed. This guarantees non-default time for the treated group, mechanically lowering observed default rates relative to firms that are never approved and do not get the same guaranteed window.

scenario: During high volatility around the Q1 2024 interest rate decision, a sell-side desk studied TechCorp’s 3‑month “rate-shock put spread” sold vs the Market Index. Trades were labeled “hedged” only if the position was still open 10 trading days after the decision (so risk could be ‘confirmed’) and then all days from decision day onward were counted as “hedged time.” The “unhedged” group included trades closed or blown out before day 10. Hedged trades showed fewer margin calls.
claim: Classifying a TechCorp derivatives book as hedged by selling the 3-month rate-shock put spread causes fewer margin calls after the Q1 2024 interest rate decision.
label: NO

X.name: Being classified as hedged via selling the TechCorp 3-month rate-shock put spread

Y.name: Margin call occurrence in the quarter after the rate decision

Z: Survival/remaining-open for the first 10 trading days after the rate decision (eligibility window)

causal_structure: Surviving 10 days without a blow-up (Z) is required to be labeled treated (X); Z also predicts fewer future margin calls (Y). Pre-day-10 time is incorrectly attributed to X, creating an artificial advantage.
key_insight: If you must survive long enough to be counted as treated, the treatment group gets guaranteed “immortal” time that inflates apparent benefits.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed due to an immortal-time/guaranteed-survival window created by the classification rule. The scenario says trades were labeled “hedged” only if the position was still open “10 trading days after the decision,” and that “all days from decision day onward were counted as ‘hedged time.’” That means the hedged group must survive the first 10 days without being closed or blowing up, while the unhedged group includes trades that fail before day 10. The apparent reduction in margin calls can be an artifact of this misclassified person-time, not a true intervention effect of the put spread.
gold_rationale: The design requires trades to remain open for 10 trading days post-decision to be labeled “hedged,” and then counts the entire post-decision window as hedged time. Any trade that suffers a margin call or is forced closed before day 10 cannot enter the hedged group, so the hedged group mechanically excludes early failures and gains guaranteed survival time, making hedging look protective even if it isn’t.

scenario: In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty, Alpha Fund launched a “CalmPulse” sentiment overlay for trading S&P 500 options. Beta Securities evaluated performance by labeling accounts as “treated” if they adopted CalmPulse by June 30, then compared April–June drawdowns versus non-adopters. Adoption required a signed addendum and 60 consecutive days of live trading history on Beta’s platform before activation, so early-April weeks were counted under the treated label.
claim: Adopting Alpha Fund’s CalmPulse overlay causes lower Q2 2024 drawdowns in S&P 500 options accounts.
label: NO

X.name: CalmPulse overlay adoption (by June 30)

Y.name: Q2 2024 maximum drawdown in S&P 500 options trading

Z: 60-day survival/eligibility window (must keep account active and trading long enough to activate CalmPulse)

causal_structure: Eligibility requires surviving/trading for 60 days → accounts that later become treated have guaranteed survival time; pre-activation period is misclassified as treated, biasing X–Y comparison.
key_insight: If you must survive long enough to receive treatment, the apparent benefit may be baked in by design.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed due to immortal-time misclassification: the study labels accounts as treated if they adopted “by June 30,” yet “Adoption required … 60 consecutive days of live trading history … before activation,” and “early-April weeks were counted under the treated label.” That means treated accounts had to survive/trade long enough to qualify, creating guaranteed survival time that is wrongly credited to CalmPulse, while the control group has no comparable requirement—so the drawdown difference isn’t a justified intervention effect.
gold_rationale: Accounts were classified as treated based on adopting by June 30, but activation required 60 consecutive days of live trading history. That creates a period in early Q2 where those eventual adopters had to remain active (and not blow up/close) to even become treated. Counting that pre-activation time as treated mechanically lowers observed drawdowns for the treated group relative to controls.

scenario: After a major policy shift widened G10 FX volatility, Bank ABC replaced its head of FX in Q3 2024. The new executive mandated a “hedge-tightening protocol” only for corporate clients whose EURUSD hedging slippage exceeded 2.5% in July–August. In September, the selected clients’ average slippage fell to 1.1%. Insurance Corp and a Credit Agency report echoed the improvement, but no comparable extreme-slippage clients were left on the old process.
claim: Mandating Bank ABC’s hedge-tightening protocol for extreme-slippage clients causes their FX hedging slippage to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Hedge-tightening protocol applied to selected corporate FX hedging accounts

Y.name: Subsequent-quarter FX hedging slippage (percentage)

Z: Selection rule: clients chosen because they had extremely high slippage (slippage > 2.5%) in the prior period

causal_structure: Z (extreme prior slippage) determines who receives X; extreme values in Z tend to move toward average on re-measurement, creating an apparent X→Y improvement even if X has no effect.
key_insight: Selecting the worst performers almost guarantees improvement next period, even without a helpful intervention.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a regression-to-the-mean problem: the group was chosen for unusually extreme outcomes, so improvement is expected even without a causal effect. The scenario says the protocol was applied “only for corporate clients whose EURUSD hedging slippage exceeded 2.5% in July–August,” and then reports that “in September, the selected clients’ average slippage fell to 1.1%,” with “no comparable extreme-slippage clients…left on the old process.” Without a control group of similarly extreme clients not receiving the protocol, the improvement does not justify the intervention claim.
gold_rationale: The protocol was applied only to clients with unusually bad recent slippage (>2.5%). Such extreme measurements commonly revert toward typical levels in the next month/quarter due to noise and changing market conditions. Because no equally extreme clients were left on the old process, the observed drop to 1.1% cannot be attributed to the protocol rather than natural reversion.

scenario: In Q4 2024’s bull market, a credit hedge fund targeted Energy Co, Green Power, and Oil Major bonds that had the worst pre-announcement selloffs (spreads widened >120 bps in the week before their dividend announcements). The PM added a “dividend-stability overlay” (reduced risk limits and added CDS hedges) only to these names. Two weeks after the dividend announcements, their average spread tightening was 70 bps. No comparable extreme-selloff names were left un-overlaid.
claim: Applying the dividend-stability overlay causes spread tightening in the selected issuers’ bonds after the dividend announcement.
label: NO

X.name: Dividend-stability overlay applied to selected bonds (risk-limit cut + CDS hedge)

Y.name: Post-announcement spread tightening (bps) in the issuers’ bonds

Z: Selection based on extreme pre-announcement spread widening (worst performers)

causal_structure: Z (extreme pre-announcement widening) determines inclusion and thus X; Z also predicts subsequent partial rebound toward typical spreads, creating an apparent X→Y effect without identifying a causal impact.
key_insight: Picking the worst movers almost guarantees a rebound, even if the overlay does nothing.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed intervention reasoning driven by regression to the mean. The scenario says the overlay was applied only to bonds that had “the worst pre-announcement selloffs (spreads widened >120 bps in the week before their dividend announcements)” and then notes they tightened afterward. Selecting extreme underperformers makes subsequent improvement likely even with no true treatment effect. With “No comparable extreme-selloff names were left un-overlaid,” there’s no control group to distinguish overlay impact from natural rebound.
gold_rationale: The portfolio manager intervened only on bonds that were extreme underperformers right before the dividend announcements. Extreme spread widening is noisy and often followed by partial normalization, especially in a bull market. Because there is no control group of similarly extreme bonds without the overlay, the observed tightening cannot be attributed to the overlay rather than natural reversion.

scenario: During a H1 2023 sector rotation out of biotech into defensives, Pharma Inc’s private-equity arm offered a “stability package” (extra IR calls and a buyback-commitment letter tied to the stock split) only to BioTech Start shareholders who had the worst Q4 2022–Jan 2023 drawdowns (bottom 10%, down 55%+). By late June after the split, this group’s average drawdown improved to -18%. No comparable non-treated extreme-loser group was tracked.
claim: Providing the stability package to the most-declined BioTech Start shareholders causes their subsequent drawdowns to shrink after the stock split.
label: NO

X.name: Stability package provided to selected BioTech Start shareholders (post–stock split support and communications)

Y.name: Subsequent reduction in shareholder drawdown by end of H1 2023

Z: Selection rule: only shareholders with extreme prior drawdowns (bottom decile, -55% or worse) were chosen

trap.subtype_name: Regression to the mean from extreme pre-selection

causal_structure: Z (extreme prior drawdown) determines who receives X; Z also predicts improvement in Y due to natural reversion from extreme outcomes, making X appear effective without identifying a causal effect.
key_insight: Picking the worst performers guarantees some rebound even if the intervention does nothing.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed because the group was selected for extreme pre-intervention performance, so improvement can occur mechanically without any treatment effect (regression to the mean). The scenario says the package was offered only to shareholders with the “worst … drawdowns (bottom 10%, down 55%+),” and then reports their drawdown “improved to -18%,” but it also notes “No comparable non-treated extreme-loser group was tracked.” Without a control group of equally extreme losers, you cannot justify that the package caused the improvement.
gold_rationale: The treated group was defined by extreme pre-intervention losses (bottom decile drawdowns). Extreme outcomes tend to be followed by less extreme outcomes even without any action. Because there is no control group of similarly extreme shareholders who did not receive the package, the post-split improvement cannot be attributed to the intervention rather than natural reversion amid a changing market regime during sector rotation.

scenario: After unexpected US inflation data in Aug 2023, a crypto exchange saw a spike in stablecoin de-pegs and flagged DeFi protocol liquidity pools with the worst slippage (bottom 5% that week). In Sep 2023 the exchange rolled out a new compliance “circuit-breaker” only for those flagged pools. By Oct–Nov (H2 2023), average slippage for that group fell from 3.8% to 1.4%, and the exchange tied this improvement to the intervention while discussing an acquisition offer involving the stablecoin issuer.
claim: Implementing the compliance circuit-breaker for high-slippage DeFi pools causes their slippage to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Compliance circuit-breaker rollout for flagged pools

Y.name: Reduction in average pool slippage (de-peg/price impact)

Z: Selection of pools based on extreme slippage (bottom 5%) during the post-data shock week

causal_structure: Z (extreme slippage week) determines who receives X; Y tends to improve mechanically after an extreme shock even without X. Without a control group, observed Y is not identifiable as an effect of X.
key_insight: Picking the worst performers and then measuring them later almost guarantees “improvement,” even if the intervention did nothing.
wise_refusal: NO. This is regression-to-the-mean reasoning. The scenario says the exchange "flagged DeFi protocol liquidity pools with the worst slippage (bottom 5% that week)" and then reported that "average slippage for that group fell from 3.8% to 1.4%." Because the subjects were chosen for an extreme one-week spike after unexpected economic data and there is no control group of similarly extreme pools without the circuit-breaker, the improvement could occur naturally as conditions normalize, so the causal intervention claim is not supported.
gold_rationale: The exchange targeted only the bottom 5% worst-slippage pools observed right after a macro shock. Extreme slippage is partly noise and transient market dislocation; subsequent readings typically move closer to normal levels. Because there is no untreated group of equally extreme pools, attributing the 3.8%→1.4% improvement to the circuit-breaker is not justified.

scenario: In late 2022, amid Russia-Ukraine-related market stress, a digital-asset market maker backed an IPO-bound stablecoin payments firm. After the IPO in 2023, an institutional fund offered a “volatility dampening” execution protocol to retail investors whose Q4 2022 slippage was in the worst 5% (avg 3.8%). By Q2 2023, this group’s average slippage fell to 1.6%. No comparable worst-5% group was tracked without the protocol.
claim: Rolling out the volatility dampening execution protocol to the worst-slippage retail investors causes their trading slippage to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Volatility dampening execution protocol offered to selected retail investors

Y.name: Subsequent reduction in retail investors' trading slippage (%)

Z: Selection of subjects based on extreme baseline slippage (worst 5% in Q4 2022)

trap.subtype_name: Regression to the mean from extreme baseline performance

causal_structure: Z (extreme baseline slippage) determines who gets X and also predicts apparent improvement in Y due to natural reversion; without a control group, X→Y is not identified.
key_insight: When you treat only the extreme tail, improvement can happen even if the treatment does nothing.
wise_refusal: NO. This is flawed due to regression to the mean from selecting an extreme group. The scenario says the protocol was offered to investors whose baseline slippage was “in the worst 5% (avg 3.8%).” Extreme slippage readings tend to improve on subsequent quarters even without any intervention. Since “No comparable worst-5% group was tracked without the protocol,” the 3.8% to 1.6% drop does not justify a causal claim that the protocol caused the improvement.
gold_rationale: The protocol was given only to retail investors selected for extremely high initial slippage (“worst 5%”). Extreme outcomes tend to move closer to average on the next measurement even without any change. Because there is no control group of similarly extreme investors who did not receive the protocol, the observed slippage drop cannot be attributed to the intervention.

scenario: Following an industry disruption and a surprise bankruptcy filing by a large renewable developer, the Treasury and Central Bank launched an “ESG liquidity backstop” for bond dealers whose ESG corporate-bond portfolios had the worst 5% one-month spread blowouts. After the backstop, this selected group’s average option-adjusted spread tightened from 420 bps to 260 bps over the next month. Officials cited the program as proof it stabilizes stressed ESG credit. No comparable non-treated extreme group was tracked.
claim: Launching the ESG liquidity backstop for dealers causes ESG corporate-bond spreads to tighten for those dealers.
label: NO

X.name: ESG liquidity backstop applied to a dealer

Y.name: subsequent tightening in ESG corporate-bond option-adjusted spreads

Z: selection of dealers based on extreme initial spread blowouts (worst 5%)

trap.subtype_name: Regression to the mean from extreme pre-selection

causal_structure: Z (extreme initial spread blowout) determines who gets X and also predicts an apparent improvement in Y on the next measurement even if X has no causal effect; X→Y is not identified without a control group.
key_insight: If you pick the worst performers, they often look better next period even with no real treatment effect.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a regression-to-the-mean problem: the program was given to dealers chosen for extreme initial stress, which will often improve on its own. The scenario says dealers were selected from “the worst 5% one-month spread blowouts,” and then “this selected group’s average… tightened from 420 bps to 260 bps over the next month.” Without “a comparable non-treated extreme group,” the tightening cannot be attributed to the backstop rather than natural reversion after an extreme month.
gold_rationale: The treated dealers were selected precisely because they had extreme spread widening (“worst 5% one-month spread blowouts”). Extreme moves in credit spreads tend to partially reverse as liquidity normalizes, so the observed tightening next month can occur mechanically even without the backstop. With no control group of similarly extreme but untreated dealers, attributing the tightening to the intervention is not justified.

scenario: During the high-volatility Q1 2024 earnings announcement window, a quant PM at RetailGiant flagged TechCorp as “valuation-dislocated” after its post-earnings gap left it in the bottom 5% of 1-day returns versus the Market Index. The desk applied a new “valuation reset” rule: buy TechCorp at the close and hold 10 trading days. Over the next two weeks, TechCorp rebounded from -12% to -2% vs the Market Index, and the PM credited the rule.
claim: Implementing RetailGiant’s 10-day “valuation reset” buying rule on TechCorp after extreme post-earnings underperformance causes TechCorp to outperform the Market Index over the next two weeks.
label: NO

X.name: Applying the 10-day 'valuation reset' rule (buy TechCorp after extreme post-earnings drop)

Y.name: TechCorp’s subsequent relative return (outperformance vs the Market Index over the next 10 trading days)

Z: Selection based on extreme initial post-earnings underperformance (bottom 5% 1-day return during volatility)

causal_structure: Z (extreme initial drop) triggers X (rule is applied only when returns are extreme) and also predicts Y (subsequent returns tend to be less extreme). Without a control group, the observed rebound is not attributable to X.
