claim: Tying trader bonuses to the Index Impact Score causes RetailGiant’s research to become more predictive of TechCorp’s post–stock-split performance.
label: NO

X.name: Bonus scheme tied to Index Impact Score

Y.name: True research predictiveness (forecast accuracy about TechCorp’s fundamentals and post-split performance)

Z: Index Impact Score (TechCorp next-day outperformance vs Market Index after notes)
Split-related order-imbalance timing and end-of-day price nudging

causal_structure: X increases incentives to optimize Z (Index Impact Score) via trading/timing tactics; Z improves mechanically while Y (true predictiveness) does not improve because the mechanism shifts from information quality to score manipulation.
key_insight: A metric that was a reasonable proxy stops reflecting the target once people are paid to optimize it.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a metric-targeting flaw: once compensation is tied to the score, the team can improve the score without improving the underlying phenomenon. The scenario says bonuses were based on “Index Impact Score” and that traders “began timing notes around split-related order-imbalance windows and routing small buys to push the close.” That behavior boosts the metric mechanically, so the higher score does not justify the claim that research became more predictive.
gold_rationale: Before the intervention, next-day relative performance after a research note could plausibly indicate whether research moved prices for information reasons. Once bonuses directly targeted that score during a split in volatile markets, traders optimized the score by exploiting predictable split-related liquidity and pushing closes, inflating measured impact without improving the underlying quality of research signals.

scenario: In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty and an acquisition offer for Beta Securities, regulators warned funds to curb insider-risk. Alpha Fund mandated that any trader at Hedge Fund X must log a “compliance attestation” in the OMS before placing orders, and management tracked a new KPI: attestation rate (target 99%). Within weeks, the KPI hit 99.5%, but audits found traders clicking attestations automatically while still trading on rumor-driven deal chatter.
claim: Mandating pre-trade compliance attestations causes improved regulatory compliance at Hedge Fund X.
label: NO

X.name: Mandatory pre-trade compliance attestation with a 99% KPI target

Y.name: True regulatory compliance (reduced insider-trading risk and policy adherence)

Z: Attestation rate KPI recorded in the order management system (OMS)

trap.subtype_name: Goodhart's Law (metric becomes target and gets gamed)

causal_structure: X directly increases Z (attestation clicks) because it is targeted and enforced; Z previously correlated with Y, but after targeting, Z is manipulable and decouples from Y, so observed Z improvement does not imply Y improved.
key_insight: A compliance checkbox can rise to 99% without reducing real insider-trading risk when people optimize the checkbox.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a metric-targeting flaw: once the KPI became the objective, it was easy to game. The scenario says Alpha Fund “tracked a new KPI: attestation rate (target 99%)” and that “audits found traders clicking attestations automatically while still trading on rumor-driven deal chatter.” That means the intervention boosts the recorded attestation metric, not necessarily real compliance. So you can’t justify that mandating attestations causes improved regulatory compliance.
gold_rationale: Attestation rate was a reasonable proxy for compliance before it became a hard KPI. Once Alpha Fund set a 99% target, traders had incentives to maximize recorded attestations (Z) rather than change behavior (Y). The metric improved quickly, but audits indicate the underlying compliance objective did not.

scenario: In Q3 2024, after a major policy shift eased rules for tokenized deposits, Bank ABC prepared for an IPO and ordered teams to boost its “Verified Digital-Asset Adoption Rate” (VDAR), a KPI partly computed from Credit Agency confirmations. Bank ABC paid Insurance Corp per “verified” wallet. VDAR jumped from 12% to 38% in six weeks, but most new wallets were pre-funded by Bank ABC and immediately dormant; fee revenue and active users stayed flat.
claim: Tying vendor payments and internal bonuses to VDAR causes genuine digital-asset adoption at Bank ABC to increase.
label: NO

X.name: Tying vendor payments and employee bonuses to the VDAR KPI

Y.name: Genuine digital-asset adoption (sustained active usage and revenue contribution)

Z: VDAR KPI level (verified wallet count/confirmation rate)

causal_structure: X directly increases Z by incentivizing creation/verification of wallets; actors manipulate what counts toward Z (pre-funded dormant wallets), so Z no longer tracks Y, and X does not reliably increase Y.
key_insight: When incentives target the proxy, the proxy inflates while the real outcome can stay unchanged.
wise_refusal: NO. The flaw is metric gaming: the intervention targets a proxy and changes what the proxy measures. The scenario says Bank ABC “paid Insurance Corp per ‘verified’ wallet” and that “most new wallets were pre-funded by Bank ABC and immediately dormant; fee revenue and active users stayed flat.” That means VDAR can be increased without any real increase in ongoing customer adoption, so the causal claim from the intervention to genuine adoption is not justified.
gold_rationale: VDAR was a reasonable proxy for adoption before it became a compensated target. Once Bank ABC linked payouts and bonuses to VDAR, teams and vendors had a strong incentive to maximize the metric itself—by creating “verified” wallets that are dormant—so the KPI rises without improving sustained usage or economics.

scenario: In Q4 2024, during a bull market, Energy Co rolled out an “ESG-linked” treasury policy: any desk holding its bonds would be evaluated on the firm’s third-party ESG score improvement. After Green Power filed for bankruptcy, Energy Co quickly sold a small, high-emission unit to Oil Major and reclassified several gas assets as “transition,” lifting its ESG score from 42 to 61. Cash-flow volatility and capex on renewables were unchanged.
claim: Tying portfolio manager evaluations to third-party ESG score improvements causes genuinely better sustainability performance at Energy Co.
label: NO

X.name: Linking evaluations/mandates to improving Energy Co’s third-party ESG score

Y.name: True sustainability performance (real emissions reduction and credible transition progress)

Z: Third-party ESG score (the targeted metric)
Asset reclassification/transaction structuring to boost the score

trap.subtype_name: Goodhart's Law (metric gaming after it becomes a target)

causal_structure: X directly pushes Z (ESG score) via reclassification and deal structuring; Z no longer reliably reflects Y once it is targeted, so observed Z improvements do not imply Y improved.
key_insight: Improving the score can be achieved by reshuffling labels and boundaries, not by improving real-world sustainability.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a metric-targeting flaw where the measure gets optimized rather than the underlying outcome. The scenario says Energy Co “sold a small, high-emission unit to Oil Major and reclassified several gas assets as ‘transition,’ lifting its ESG score from 42 to 61,” while “cash-flow volatility and capex on renewables were unchanged.” That indicates the ESG score was improved through boundary/label changes and deal structuring, so the score no longer reliably reflects real emissions reductions or transition progress. Therefore the intervention doesn’t justify the claim about genuine sustainability performance.
gold_rationale: Before the mandate, the ESG score plausibly summarized sustainability signals. Once Energy Co tied investment evaluations to score gains, the firm had incentive to maximize the score directly. The scenario states the score rose due to selling a high-emission unit and reclassifying assets, while cash-flow risk and renewable investment did not change—evidence the metric was manipulated and ceased to measure true sustainability progress.

scenario: In H1 2023, during a healthcare-to-energy sector rotation, Pharma Inc and BioTech Start both faced an FDA decision risk. Ahead of their earnings announcements, Pharma Inc’s CFO told IR to “maximize the post-earnings valuation multiple” by tying exec bonuses to the next-day P/E shown on major data terminals. After earnings, the displayed P/E fell from 28x to 18x, and management claimed the intervention improved true valuation discipline.
claim: Tying executive bonuses to the next-day displayed P/E multiple causes Pharma Inc’s valuation to become more attractive in a fundamental sense.
label: NO

X.name: Executive bonus plan tied to next-day displayed P/E multiple

Y.name: Fundamental valuation attractiveness (true improvement in intrinsic value/expected cash flows relative to price)

Z: Displayed next-day P/E multiple on market data terminals (the targeted metric)

trap.subtype_name: Goodhart's Law (metric gaming after becoming a target)

causal_structure: X directly incentivizes changes that reduce Z (reported/visible P/E) via earnings presentation and accounting choices; Z no longer reliably indicates Y because it is manipulated, so the observed improvement in Z does not imply improvement in Y.
key_insight: A cleaner-looking multiple can be manufactured; once rewarded, the multiple stops being a trustworthy proxy for true value.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a metric-targeting flaw where the measure can be gamed. The scenario says the CFO told IR to “maximize the post-earnings valuation multiple” and tied bonuses to “the next-day P/E shown on major data terminals.” That means the intervention targets the metric directly. The resulting drop in the displayed P/E (28x to 18x) can come from manipulating what feeds into the terminal P/E around earnings, so the metric no longer reflects fundamental valuation. The claim fails because improving the displayed multiple does not show intrinsic value or cash-flow prospects improved—only that the reported metric looks better.
gold_rationale: Before the bonus plan, the displayed forward P/E was a reasonable shorthand for how expensive Pharma Inc looked versus peers. Once management tied compensation to that terminal-displayed multiple, they had incentives to alter how earnings were presented and what ‘E’ the market’s data feeds used, improving the metric without necessarily improving underlying expected cash flows or risk—invalidating the causal claim about true valuation attractiveness.

scenario: In H2 2023, after unexpected US inflation data spiked volatility, a Crypto Exchange announced a merger with a DeFi Protocol and a Stablecoin issuer. To “prove healthier liquidity,” the exchange began paying market makers rebates only if they kept the top-of-book spread under 2 bps (the KPI shown to investors). Spreads tightened immediately, but makers started posting tiny spoof-like quotes and pulling depth milliseconds later, leaving real executable size unchanged during selloffs.
claim: Paying rebates conditional on keeping the top-of-book spread under 2 bps causes improved market liquidity on the exchange.
label: NO

X.name: Rebate program tied to maintaining sub-2 bps top-of-book spread

Y.name: True market liquidity (real executable depth and price impact during stress)

Z: Displayed top-of-book spread KPI (now strategically managed)

trap.subtype_name: Goodhart's Law (metric becomes target and gets gamed)

causal_structure: X directly incentivizes Z (quoted spread) to look better; participants manipulate quoting behavior so Z improves while Y (executable depth/price impact) does not improve.
key_insight: Tightening a quoted-spread KPI can be manufactured without improving executable liquidity.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a metric-targeting flaw: the intervention rewards the KPI itself, so participants can game it. The scenario says rebates were paid only if makers kept “the top-of-book spread under 2 bps (the KPI shown to investors),” and that makers then posted “tiny…quotes and pull[ed] depth milliseconds later,” leaving “real executable size unchanged during selloffs.” That means the spread metric no longer reflects true liquidity, so you can’t conclude the rebate program causes improved market liquidity.
gold_rationale: The scenario states the exchange targeted a liquidity proxy—top-of-book spread—by paying rebates conditional on that metric. Market makers respond by optimizing the metric via tiny, fleeting quotes and rapid cancellations, improving the displayed spread without increasing real executable size. Thus the observed KPI change cannot justify the intervention claim about true liquidity.

scenario: In 2022, amid geopolitical tensions, regulators required institutional funds to report a weekly “hedge coverage ratio” (HCR) and warned of scrutiny if HCR fell below 90%. A large institutional fund then mandated its desk keep HCR ≥95% daily. Reported HCR rose from 82% to 97%. Market makers noted the fund increasingly used ultra-short-dated options that boost reported HCR but expire before key risk windows; drawdowns during overnight gaps in 2023 did not improve.
claim: Mandating a higher reported hedge coverage ratio (HCR) causes the fund’s true downside risk to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Policy to mandate HCR ≥95% as a monitored target

Y.name: True downside risk (tail-loss/drawdown severity during stress moves)

Z: Reported hedge coverage ratio (HCR) metric influenced by instrument choice (e.g., ultra-short-dated options/roll timing)

trap.subtype_name: Goodhart's Law (metric gaming under regulatory/comp targets)

causal_structure: X directly incentivizes improving Z (reported HCR). Traders can manipulate Z via hedge instrument selection/roll timing without materially changing Y; thus Z no longer reliably tracks Y after X.
key_insight: When a risk proxy becomes a target, desks optimize the proxy (HCR) rather than the underlying tail risk.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a metric-targeting flaw where the measure gets optimized instead of the underlying risk. The scenario says the fund “mandated its desk keep HCR ≥95% daily” and that it used “ultra-short-dated options that boost reported HCR but expire before key risk windows,” while “drawdowns during overnight gaps in 2023 did not improve.” That indicates the HCR metric was gamed, so a higher reported HCR does not justify a causal claim about reducing true downside risk.
gold_rationale: Before the mandate, HCR plausibly indicated how much exposure was hedged. After regulators and management tied scrutiny to a numeric threshold, the desk optimized the reported ratio by using positions that score well on HCR but provide little protection when the actual risk materializes (e.g., hedges expiring before overnight geopolitical gaps). The metric improved, but the underlying phenomenon—tail-loss protection—did not.

scenario: After an industry disruption and a bond-market correction over the last 12 months, the Treasury and Central Bank launched a “Liquidity Support Score” for primary dealers, based on each dealer’s average on-screen bid–ask spread in benchmark bonds. Access to the new facility and fee rebates were tied to improving that spread. Spreads tightened sharply, but dealers shifted volume to the scored benchmarks while widening spreads and reducing depth in off-benchmark issues and using tiny “show” quotes to keep the score low.
claim: Tying facility access and fee rebates to dealers’ Liquidity Support Score causes bond market liquidity to improve.
label: NO

X.name: Linking facility access/fee rebates to the Liquidity Support Score

Y.name: True bond market liquidity (depth and tradability across the curve, including off-benchmark issues)

Z: Liquidity Support Score based on average on-screen bid–ask spread in benchmark bonds (metric)

causal_structure: X directly pressures dealers to optimize Z (reported benchmark bid–ask spreads). Z previously correlated with Y, but after X, dealers manipulate quoting/venue selection so Z improves while Y (broad, usable liquidity) does not.
key_insight: Improving a targeted liquidity metric can reflect gaming, not real liquidity.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a metric-targeting flaw: the intervention rewards the Liquidity Support Score rather than liquidity itself. The scenario states that access and rebates were 'tied to improving that spread' and that dealers used 'tiny “show” quotes' and 'shifted volume to the scored benchmarks while widening spreads and reducing depth in off-benchmark issues.' That means the metric is being gamed, so tighter scored spreads do not justify the claim that true bond market liquidity improved.
gold_rationale: The intervention explicitly targets a proxy for liquidity (average benchmark bid–ask spread). Once incentives are tied to that proxy, dealers can strategically alter quoting behavior and shift liquidity away from unscored segments, making the metric look better without improving market-wide tradability. The apparent improvement is therefore not valid evidence of a causal improvement in true liquidity.

scenario: In Q1 2024, during high volatility around a surprise interest rate decision, RetailGiant asked TechCorp to structure a “capital-protection” note linked to a broad Market Index. RetailGiant tied desk bonuses to the product’s reported “99% 1-day VaR” staying below 0.8%. VaR immediately dropped from 1.4% to 0.6%, but traders shifted risk into gap exposure and illiquid options so losses showed up beyond 1 day and outside the VaR window.
claim: Tying TechCorp’s structuring and trading bonuses to keeping reported 99% 1-day VaR below 0.8% causes the portfolio’s true risk to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Bonuses/mandate tied to reported 99% 1-day VaR threshold (0.8%)

Y.name: True portfolio risk of the structured note book (tail loss exposure during volatility)

Z: Reported 99% 1-day VaR metric (model/window-dependent and now strategically managed)

causal_structure: X directly incentivizes minimizing Z (reported VaR) via position design and model/tenor selection; Z improves while risk is displaced into unmeasured dimensions, so Y does not decrease (and may increase).
key_insight: Optimizing a risk metric can reduce the number without reducing the risk.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a metric-targeting failure: the intervention optimizes the reported risk number, not the underlying risk. The scenario explicitly says bonuses were tied to the metric—“tied desk bonuses to the product’s reported ‘99% 1-day VaR’ staying below 0.8%”—and that traders responded by “shift[ing] risk into gap exposure and illiquid options so losses showed up beyond 1 day and outside the VaR window.” That means the VaR drop can be explained by gaming the measurement, so you can’t infer the portfolio’s true tail risk fell.
gold_rationale: The scenario states VaR was used as a proxy for risk, then became a target via bonuses. After the intervention, desks changed how risk was taken so the reported 1-day VaR fell while risk moved into areas VaR doesn’t capture (gap risk, illiquid options, longer-horizon losses). The metric improvement therefore doesn’t justify the claim that true risk decreased.

scenario: In Q2 2024 amid economic uncertainty, Alpha Fund launched a new “CalmYield” note via Beta Securities. To boost distribution, Beta paid its sales desk per account opened and used “7‑day net inflows” as the KPI. Within weeks, reported inflows jumped from $20M/week to $120M/week, but clients were encouraged to park cash for 8–10 days and then rotate out, while some flows were internally recycled between affiliated accounts. Real client stickiness and risk-adjusted performance did not improve.
claim: Tying Beta Securities’ sales compensation to 7-day net inflows causes Alpha Fund’s product launch to achieve stronger genuine investor demand and distribution quality.
label: NO

X.name: Sales compensation tied to the 7-day net inflows KPI for CalmYield

Y.name: Genuine investor demand / distribution quality for CalmYield (sticky, informed, long-horizon allocations)

Z: 7-day net inflows KPI (targeted metric)
Short-term parking/recycling of flows across affiliated or coordinated accounts
Account-opening incentives that favor quantity over suitability

causal_structure: X directly increases Z (reported 7-day net inflows) by incentivizing short-term parking and recycled flows; Z no longer reliably reflects Y, so the observed KPI improvement does not imply a causal increase in genuine demand (Y).
key_insight: When you pay people to hit an inflow KPI, you may get inflows that are engineered—not real demand.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a metric-targeting flaw where the KPI can be gamed. The scenario says Beta “paid its sales desk per account opened and used ‘7-day net inflows’ as the KPI” and that clients were “encouraged to park cash for 8–10 days and then rotate out,” with flows “internally recycled.” That means the measured inflows improved because the metric was manipulated, while “real client stickiness and risk-adjusted performance did not improve,” so the intervention does not justify a claim about genuine demand.
gold_rationale: Before the compensation change, 7-day net inflows plausibly indicated whether the launch was attracting real investor capital. After Beta tied pay to that KPI, the desk had an incentive to maximize the metric itself, leading to short-term cash parking and recycled flows that inflate reported inflows without improving investor stickiness or product adoption quality.

scenario: In Q3 2024, after a major policy shift widened FX volatility, Bank ABC appointed a new CFO and launched an intervention: automatic “stability hedges” that pre-emptively sell USD and buy the local currency whenever intraday USD spikes exceed 1%. Insurance Corp, seeing the rule, began front-running the trigger with short-dated options. Credit Agency then warned about rising hedging losses. After rollout, USD buying pressure increased and the local currency fell 4% in two weeks.
claim: Implementing Bank ABC’s automatic stability-hedge program causes the local currency to appreciate against the USD.
label: NO

X.name: Automatic stability-hedge rule (sell USD/buy local currency when USD spikes >1%)

Y.name: Local currency appreciation versus USD over Q3 2024

Z: Market participant front-running/defensive positioning (options and spot) triggered by predictable hedging rule

causal_structure: X makes Bank ABC’s hedging demand predictable, which increases Z (front-running and option-driven hedging by other institutions); Z increases USD demand and selling pressure on the local currency, pushing Y in the opposite direction of intended.
key_insight: A rule-based stabilizing intervention can become a target—predictability invites positioning that reverses the intended price impact.
wise_refusal: NO. This is the backfire-effect trap: the intervention triggers oppositional/compensatory trading that overwhelms the intended stabilizing flow. The scenario says, “Insurance Corp… began front-running the trigger with short-dated options,” and after rollout “USD buying pressure increased and the local currency fell 4%.” Because the hedging rule is predictable, it invites front-running and option-market hedging dynamics that can increase USD demand, so you can’t justify the claim that the program causes appreciation.
gold_rationale: The claim assumes Bank ABC’s USD-selling hedges will strengthen the local currency. But the scenario embeds a compensatory response: Insurance Corp “began front-running the trigger with short-dated options,” which can force dealers to buy USD and amplify moves. The observed outcome (“local currency fell 4%”) is opposite the intended direction, consistent with an intervention that backfires.

scenario: In Q4 2024’s bull market, Energy Co announced a special dividend and told bond investors it would fund it by selling non-core assets to “strengthen credit.” After the announcement, Energy Co’s 5-year CDS widened from 210 bps to 320 bps and its 2029 bonds fell 4 points. Dealers reported credit funds shorted the bonds, arguing the dividend signaled shareholder-first behavior and increased future leverage risk versus peers like Green Power and Oil Major.
claim: Announcing a special dividend funded by asset sales causes Energy Co’s credit spreads to tighten.
label: NO

X.name: Special dividend announcement framed as credit-positive (asset-sale funded)

Y.name: Tightening in Energy Co credit risk pricing (lower CDS / higher bond prices)

Z: Creditor backlash and defensive repositioning (perceived higher shareholder extraction → shorting/selling pressure)
Signal-induced reassessment of future leverage and covenant protection

causal_structure: X is intended to improve perceived credit quality, but X triggers Z (negative signal + creditor reactance), and Z pushes Y in the opposite direction (spreads widen / bonds drop).
key_insight: A “credit-positive” dividend message can backfire if it signals shareholder extraction, prompting creditors to demand more spread.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a backfire-effect trap: the intervention triggers an oppositional response that reverses the intended direction. The scenario states that “after the announcement, Energy Co’s 5-year CDS widened from 210 bps to 320 bps and its 2029 bonds fell 4 points” and that “credit funds shorted the bonds, arguing the dividend signaled shareholder-first behavior.” That creditor backlash (selling/shorting and higher required spread) is a compensatory reaction to the dividend, so you can’t justify the claim that announcing the dividend causes spreads to tighten; the observed mechanism points to widening instead.
gold_rationale: The claim assumes the dividend announcement mechanically improves credit by highlighting asset sales. But the scenario embeds an opposite realized effect: CDS widens and bonds sell off right after the announcement. A plausible backfire mechanism is that creditors view the dividend as shareholder extraction and a negative signal about future financial policy, triggering selling/shorting that overwhelms any intended “credit-positive” narrative.

scenario: In H1 2023, during a sector rotation out of biotech into energy/value, Pharma Inc announced a 10-for-1 stock split to “improve liquidity” and attract long-only buyers. Instead, retail flow surged and weekly call buying spiked; market makers hedged by shorting stock, and several private-equity crossover funds used the split-induced liquidity to exit blocks. BioTech Start’s sympathy split chatter saw similar option-driven selling pressure. Pharma Inc’s shares fell 18% over the next two weeks.
claim: Announcing a stock split causes Pharma Inc’s share price to rise by attracting new buyers.
label: NO

X.name: Pharma Inc announces a 10-for-1 stock split (H1 2023)

Y.name: Pharma Inc share price increases in the following weeks

Z: Retail-driven call-option frenzy and dealer delta-hedging short pressure
Crossover/private-equity funds using improved liquidity to exit positions during sector rotation

causal_structure: X increases perceived tradability/attention, which triggers Z (speculative options demand and opportunistic selling). Z creates net selling/shorting pressure that dominates any intended buy-side liquidity effect, pushing Y in the opposite direction.
key_insight: An intervention meant to attract buyers can instead activate selling/hedging forces that overwhelm it.
wise_refusal: NO. This is the backfire-effect trap: the intervention triggers compensatory/oppositional responses that reverse the intended impact. The scenario says, "retail flow surged and weekly call buying spiked; market makers hedged by shorting stock," and "crossover funds used the split-induced liquidity to exit blocks." Those post-split reactions create selling/short pressure that plausibly explains why "shares fell 18%"—so you can’t justify that doing the split causes the price to rise.
gold_rationale: The claim assumes the stock split’s intended mechanism (more buyers via improved liquidity) will raise the price. But the scenario embeds an oppositional response: the split catalyzes speculative call demand that induces dealer shorting (delta hedging) and provides a convenient liquidity window for crossover/private-equity sellers to unload shares. Those reactions push the stock down—opposite the intended direction—so the intervention claim isn’t justified.

scenario: In H2 2023, after an unexpected hot CPI print spiked volatility, a major Crypto Exchange offered to acquire a struggling DeFi Protocol that powered a popular Stablecoin. Management planned to reassure markets by publicly announcing a strict “compliance-first” policy: mandatory KYC on all protocol front-ends and immediate geo-blocking of flagged jurisdictions. Within two weeks of the announcement, on-chain activity shifted to unofficial front-ends, and the stablecoin’s de-peg frequency increased as liquidity fragmented.
claim: Announcing and enforcing strict KYC and geo-blocking on the DeFi Protocol causes the Stablecoin to become more stable (fewer de-pegs).
label: NO

X.name: Strict KYC + geo-blocking enforcement on DeFi protocol front-ends

Y.name: Stablecoin stability (lower de-peg frequency and tighter peg deviations)

Z: User and liquidity-provider migration to unofficial front-ends/competitor pools (regulatory arbitrage)
Liquidity fragmentation and thinner market depth during volatility

causal_structure: X is intended to improve Y, but X increases Z (migration/fragmentation), and Z worsens Y; the induced response overwhelms the intended stabilizing channel, producing the opposite effect.
key_insight: A compliance intervention can push activity into harder-to-monitor venues, reducing liquidity and making pegs less stable.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a backfire-effect trap (T17): the intervention triggers compensatory behavior that overwhelms the intended stabilizing mechanism. The scenario says that after the exchange announced “mandatory KYC… and geo-blocking,” “on-chain activity shifted to unofficial front-ends, and the stablecoin’s de-peg frequency increased as liquidity fragmented.” That reaction (migration/fragmentation) plausibly reduces market depth and makes the peg less stable, so you can’t justify the claim that stricter enforcement causes fewer de-pegs.
gold_rationale: The claim assumes stricter compliance directly stabilizes the stablecoin. But the scenario states that after the policy, activity moved to unofficial front-ends and de-pegs increased as liquidity fragmented—an oppositional response that reverses the intended direction. This is a classic backfire: the intervention prompts regulatory arbitrage and thinner depth, worsening peg stability.

scenario: During 2022–2023 geopolitical tensions, a digital-asset exchange went public via IPO. To calm post-IPO volatility, the Market Maker began publishing “stability bands” and automatically widening spreads whenever the Retail Investor order-flow became one-sided. After the change, Retail Investors on social media coordinated to “break the bands,” repeatedly sweeping the book. The Institutional Fund reduced passive liquidity, and intraday volatility rose sharply versus the prior month.
claim: Publishing stability bands and widening spreads during one-sided flow causes post-IPO volatility to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Market Maker publishes stability bands and auto-widens spreads during one-sided retail flow

Y.name: Post-IPO intraday volatility (realized volatility) decreases

Z: Retail Investor oppositional coordination/reactance to "break the bands" (liquidity-taking surges, less passive liquidity)

causal_structure: X changes market microstructure and signals fragility, triggering Z (oppositional retail coordination and institutional pullback), which increases volatility; the net effect of X on Y is opposite the intended direction.
key_insight: An intervention that looks stabilizing can invite adversarial behavior that amplifies the very outcome it aims to reduce.
wise_refusal: NO. This is a backfire-effect trap: the intervention provokes oppositional behavior that reverses the intended impact. The scenario says, "Retail Investors on social media coordinated to 'break the bands,' repeatedly sweeping the book" and "The Institutional Fund reduced passive liquidity" after the Market Maker began "publishing 'stability bands'" and widening spreads. Those reactions reduce depth and increase aggressive liquidity-taking, so the intervention is not justified as causing volatility to decrease.
gold_rationale: The claim assumes the Market Maker’s stability bands mechanically reduce volatility. But the scenario states the opposite happened after the intervention: retail traders coordinated to “break the bands,” and an Institutional Fund pulled passive liquidity. These compensatory/oppositional responses plausibly overwhelm any stabilizing intent, producing higher volatility (a backfire).

scenario: Over the last 12 months, after an industry disruption, a large “green” infrastructure developer filed for bankruptcy, widening ESG credit spreads and freezing new issuance. To stabilize the bond market, the Central Bank and Treasury announced an intervention: preferential repo haircuts and a temporary purchase facility for high-ESG-labeled corporate bonds to lower funding costs and revive issuance. Within weeks, dealers and funds crowded into the eligible ESG bucket, while shunning non-eligible bonds; bid-ask spreads in the eligible bonds widened and yields rose as shorts and hedges piled in.
claim: Launching the Central Bank–Treasury ESG bond purchase and preferential repo program causes ESG corporate bond yields to fall and market liquidity to improve.
label: NO

X.name: Central Bank–Treasury preferential repo haircuts and purchase facility for high-ESG-labeled corporate bonds

Y.name: Lower ESG corporate bond yields and improved liquidity (tighter spreads / narrower bid-ask)

Z: crowding/positioning and adversarial trading (basis trades, shorting and hedging against the facility-eligible basket)
eligibility-driven stigma and liquidity withdrawal from non-eligible bonds spilling back into dealer balance-sheet constraints

causal_structure: X is intended to reduce yields and improve liquidity, but X induces Z (crowding, stigma, and adversarial positioning) that overwhelms the intended channel, pushing Y in the opposite direction (higher yields/worse liquidity).
key_insight: An intervention can worsen the target market when it triggers compensatory behavior that dominates the intended support channel.
wise_refusal: NO. This is the backfire-effect trap: the intervention triggers oppositional/compensatory responses that flip the sign of the outcome. The scenario says that after the program, “dealers and funds crowded into the eligible ESG bucket” and “bid-ask spreads in the eligible bonds widened and yields rose as shorts and hedges piled in.” That is the opposite of the claim’s predicted direction (lower yields, better liquidity), so the causal intervention claim isn’t justified from these facts.
gold_rationale: The claim assumes the ESG facility mechanically lowers yields and improves liquidity. But the scenario embeds a compensatory response: “dealers and funds crowded into the eligible ESG bucket” and “bid-ask spreads in the eligible bonds widened and yields rose as shorts and hedges piled in.” The intervention changes incentives, creating congestion, stigma spillovers, and adversarial trading that reverses the intended effect.

scenario: In Q1 2024, during high market volatility, TechCorp’s earnings announcement triggered a sharp selloff and widened options implied volatility. A market-maker desk proposed an intervention: aggressively selling TechCorp call options and buying puts (a large collar) to “cap upside and stabilize the tape,” expecting TechCorp’s realized volatility and beta to the Market Index to fall. After similar collars were put on, TechCorp’s intraday swings grew as hedging flows hit.
claim: Aggressively implementing a TechCorp collar (sell calls, buy puts) after the earnings announcement causes TechCorp’s realized volatility and Market Index beta to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Aggressive post-earnings collar on TechCorp (sell calls + buy puts)

Y.name: Lower realized volatility and lower beta of TechCorp versus the Market Index

Z: Dealer gamma/vega hedging feedback (delta-hedging flows that amplify moves)
Liquidity withdrawal and wider spreads during volatile tape
RetailGiant-style retail flow chasing breakouts/downswing momentum

causal_structure: X increases Z (dealer hedging feedback and liquidity withdrawal), and Z increases Y (realized volatility/beta), overwhelming the intended dampening effect of X.
key_insight: An intervention meant to damp volatility can provoke hedging and liquidity reactions that amplify volatility instead.
wise_refusal: NO. This is the Backfire Effect (T17): the intervention can trigger compensatory market microstructure responses that overwhelm the intended stabilizing mechanism. The scenario notes that after the collar flows, “TechCorp’s intraday swings grew as hedging flows hit,” indicating the options trade induced dealer delta-hedging and liquidity withdrawal that amplified, rather than reduced, realized volatility and beta. Because the claim ignores these oppositional reactions, the intervention effect is not justified.
gold_rationale: The claim assumes the collar mechanically stabilizes TechCorp. But the scenario embeds the opposite outcome: after similar collars, “TechCorp’s intraday swings grew as hedging flows hit.” A large options position can flip dealers short gamma during a volatile tape, forcing procyclical hedging that intensifies price moves and can raise co-movement with the Market Index—i.e., the intervention backfires.

scenario: In Q2 2024 amid economic uncertainty, Alpha Fund asked Beta Securities to impose a higher minimum resting time (200ms) on Alpha’s orders right after a merger announcement that had made the stock jumpy. The intent was to reduce Alpha’s adverse selection and slippage. Instead, Hedge Fund X detected the predictable “stuck” quotes and aggressively hit Alpha’s resting liquidity, and Alpha’s average execution slippage widened from 6 bps to 11 bps over the next two weeks.
claim: Imposing a higher minimum resting time on Alpha Fund’s orders causes Alpha’s execution slippage to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Beta Securities imposes a 200ms minimum resting time on Alpha Fund orders

Y.name: Alpha Fund execution slippage (bps) decreases

Z: Hedge Fund X opportunistic targeting of predictable resting quotes (latency-arbitrage/quote-hitting behavior)

causal_structure: X changes market microstructure by making Alpha’s quotes predictable/less cancelable, which increases Z (oppositional trading by Hedge Fund X), and Z increases slippage; the induced response overwhelms the intended protective effect, flipping the sign of the outcome.
key_insight: An intervention that constrains behavior can invite strategic exploitation that makes the outcome worse.
wise_refusal: NO. This is the Backfire Effect (T17): the intervention triggers an oppositional response that overwhelms the intended benefit. The scenario says, "Hedge Fund X detected the predictable 'stuck' quotes and aggressively hit Alpha’s resting liquidity" and "Alpha’s average execution slippage widened from 6 bps to 11 bps." Because the rule makes Alpha’s orders harder to cancel, it becomes easier to be picked off, so imposing a higher resting time is more likely to increase slippage rather than decrease it.
gold_rationale: The claim assumes the intervention (minimum resting time) mechanically reduces slippage. But the scenario describes a compensatory/oppositional reaction: Hedge Fund X exploits the new predictability and hits Alpha’s resting quotes. The observed effect is the opposite of intended (slippage rises from 6 bps to 11 bps), indicating the intervention backfires.

scenario: In Q3 2024, following a major policy shift, a regulatory change required banks to apply a 100% risk weight to any single-name CDS hedge purchased from a counterparty rated below A- unless the hedge was novated to an A- or better rated central clearing member. Bank ABC’s credit desk had bought $200 million notional of 5-year CDS protection from Insurance Corp, which Credit Agency downgraded to BBB+ in August 2024. Because the hedge no longer qualified, Bank ABC’s internal capital engine (implemented to mirror the new rule) set hedge recognition to zero, and the bank had to post an additional $18 million in regulatory capital for that exposure in September 2024.
claim: If Credit Agency had not downgraded Insurance Corp to BBB+ in August 2024 (i.e., it had remained A- or better), then Bank ABC would not have had to post the additional $18 million in regulatory capital in September 2024.
label: VALID

X.name: Credit Agency downgraded Insurance Corp to BBB+ in Aug 2024, making it below A-

Y.name: Bank ABC posted an additional $18 million in regulatory capital in Sep 2024 due to loss of hedge recognition

Z: Regulatory change in Q3 2024: CDS hedges from counterparties rated below A- receive 0% hedge recognition unless novated to an A- (or better) clearing member
Bank ABC capital engine rule: if counterparty rating < A- and no novation flag, set hedge_recognition = 0 deterministically
No novation occurred for the Insurance Corp CDS during Q3 2024
variables.X': Insurance Corp remained rated A- or better in Aug 2024

causal_structure: X changed the counterparty rating status relative to a hard threshold in Z, which deterministically switched hedge recognition off, directly forcing the incremental capital Y; with X' the threshold would not be breached, so the switch would not occur.
key_insight: When a rule is a hard threshold, crossing it is a deterministic switch: change the threshold variable and the outcome flips.
wise_refusal: VALID. The causal identification is sound because the regulatory change created a deterministic eligibility rule: if the hedge seller is rated below A- and the hedge is not novated, Bank ABC must treat the CDS hedge as providing zero regulatory relief, which mechanically increases required capital. The scenario states the downgrade to BBB+ occurred and that no novation happened, so the downgrade is the but-for trigger that made the hedge ineligible under the fixed rule. Alternative explanations (market volatility, widening spreads, discretionary management choice) are ruled out by the stated invariant that the capital engine follows the regulation deterministically and by holding the exposure, notional, and lack of novation constant across worlds.
gold_rationale: This is F1 because the mapping from counterparty rating status to hedge recognition and capital is explicitly rule-based and implemented deterministically in Bank ABC’s capital engine. The counterfactual hinges on whether the mechanism (a hard A- threshold with no novation exception triggered) would still operate the same way under X'. Since X' prevents breaching the threshold, the deterministic switch that caused the extra capital would not trigger.

scenario: In Q4 2024, during a market correction inside an otherwise bull market, Energy Co’s treasury desk had a standing algorithmic rule to buy protection on its floating-rate debt: it would enter a 3-month SOFR interest-rate cap at a 5.00% strike whenever 3-month SOFR fixed at or above 5.00% on two consecutive trading days. On Oct 21–22, 2024, 3-month SOFR fixed at 5.02% and 5.01%, so the desk executed the cap purchase. The cap premium was $4.0M, and by December SOFR fell below 5.00%, so the cap never paid out; the premium was expensed, and analysts cited the $4.0M as a drag on Q4 earnings versus peers like Green Power and Oil Major.
claim: If 3-month SOFR had fixed at 4.99% (instead of at least 5.00%) on Oct 21–22, 2024, then Energy Co would not have paid the $4.0M cap premium in Q4 2024.
label: VALID

X.name: 3-month SOFR fixed at or above 5.00% on two consecutive trading days (Oct 21–22, 2024)

Y.name: Energy Co paid the $4.0M premium for the 3-month 5.00% strike SOFR cap in Q4 2024

Z: Treasury policy: deterministic execution rule 'buy cap iff SOFR >= 5.00% for 2 consecutive fixes'
Execution constraint: once triggered, the trade is executed same day at the quoted premium
Instrument terms: cap premium is paid upfront and non-refundable
variables.X': 3-month SOFR fixed at 4.99% on Oct 21–22, 2024 (i.e., not at or above 5.00% on both days)

causal_structure: X deterministically triggers the hedge execution rule Z, which directly causes Y (premium payment); without X, the rule does not trigger and Y does not occur.
key_insight: When a policy is 'execute iff condition holds,' changing the condition below the threshold deterministically removes the downstream payment.
wise_refusal: VALID. The causal identification is sound because the premium payment was mechanically caused by a deterministic policy: Energy Co paid the cap premium if and only if the two-day SOFR fixing condition (>=5.00% both days) was met. The scenario states direct evidence for the link: SOFR fixed at 5.02% and 5.01% on Oct 21–22, which triggered the rule and resulted in the $4.0M upfront, non-refundable premium payment. Alternative explanations (e.g., discretionary hedging during the market correction, peer actions, or later SOFR declines) are ruled out by the stated invariants: the execution is automatic upon the trigger, and the only counterfactual change is the fixing level; with 4.99% the trigger would not have fired, so the trade—and the premium payment—would not have occurred.
gold_rationale: This is an F1 deterministic counterfactual: the outcome (paying the premium) is governed by an explicit, binary treasury rule. The correct judgment hinges on recognizing the invariant mechanism—an 'if and only if' trigger—rather than inferring from market sentiment during the correction or peer behavior (Green Power, Oil Major).

scenario: In H1 2023, during a sector rotation out of biotech after a hawkish FDA-related risk-off tone and an interest rate decision that widened credit spreads, Pharma Inc held a $50 million principal-protected note linked to BioTech Start’s stock. The note’s term sheet had an automatic knockout: if BioTech Start’s stock ever closed at or above 120% of its initial level on any trading day, the note redeemed immediately at 100% principal plus a fixed 8% coupon. On May 18, 2023, BioTech Start closed at 121% of the initial level, so the note auto-redeemed the next business day and Pharma Inc received principal plus the 8% coupon; it did not participate in BioTech Start’s subsequent +35% rally into late June.
claim: If BioTech Start’s stock had not closed at or above 120% of its initial level on May 18, 2023, then Pharma Inc’s note would not have auto-redeemed the next business day.
label: VALID

X.name: On May 18, 2023, BioTech Start’s stock closed at 121% of the note’s initial reference level (breaching the 120% knockout).

Y.name: The note auto-redeemed on the next business day (ending Pharma Inc’s exposure).

Z: Note term sheet: deterministic auto-call/knockout rule (close >= 120% triggers immediate redemption next business day)
Official closing price as published by the primary listing exchange (used for barrier observation)
Operational convention: redemption occurs next business day after a trigger close
variables.X': On May 18, 2023, BioTech Start’s stock closed below 120% of the note’s initial reference level (no knockout breach).

causal_structure: X (barrier close breach) deterministically triggered Y (automatic redemption) via Z (hard-coded contract rule) with no alternate causal path to redemption absent a breach.
key_insight: When a payoff event is hard-coded in a term sheet, changing whether the trigger condition is met deterministically changes whether the event occurs.
wise_refusal: VALID. The causal identification is sound because the note’s auto-redemption was mechanistically determined by a single explicit term-sheet rule: a close at or above 120% necessarily and sufficienty triggered next-business-day redemption. The evidence is the stated contract language (close-based barrier observation and automatic redemption timing) and the observed close at 121% that satisfied the trigger in the actual world. Alternative explanations (e.g., the interest rate decision, sector rotation, or FDA headlines) are ruled out as direct causes of redemption because, under the stated invariants, those factors affect the stock path but do not independently trigger redemption without the barrier condition being met.
gold_rationale: This is an F1 deterministic counterfactual: the outcome (auto-redemption) is governed by a rule-based contractual mechanism that fires if and only if a precisely defined condition (close >= 120%) occurs. The reasoning hinges on recognizing the invariant term-sheet rule, not extrapolating from market correlations around the interest rate decision or sector rotation.

scenario: In August 2023, right after a hotter-than-expected U.S. CPI print, a Crypto Exchange launched a new "instant mint" feature for a Stablecoin that automatically routed user deposits into a partnered DeFi Protocol to farm yield. The DeFi Protocol’s smart contract had a hard-coded rule: if the Stablecoin’s on-chain price oracle reported < $0.99, deposits were rejected and any attempted mint was reverted. During the launch hour, the oracle briefly printed $0.985 due to thin liquidity, so the exchange’s mint transactions reverted and no new Stablecoin was issued through the feature.
claim: If the Stablecoin’s oracle price had not dipped below $0.99 during the launch hour, then the Crypto Exchange would have successfully minted Stablecoin via the instant-mint feature.
label: VALID

X.name: During the launch hour, the oracle reported the Stablecoin price at $0.985 (< $0.99), triggering the DeFi Protocol’s rejection condition

Y.name: The Crypto Exchange successfully minted Stablecoin through the instant-mint feature (i.e., mint transactions were not reverted and Stablecoin supply increased via that route)

Z: DeFi Protocol smart-contract guardrail: revert deposit/mint if oracle price < $0.99
Atomic transaction semantics on-chain (a revert means no state change, no mint)
Exchange routing logic that always calls the DeFi Protocol contract during instant mint
variables.X': During the launch hour, the oracle reported the Stablecoin price at or above $0.99, so the rejection condition would not have triggered

causal_structure: X (oracle price below threshold) deterministically triggered Z (contract revert), which deterministically prevented Y (successful mint); changing X to X' removes the only blocking mechanism.
key_insight: When a smart contract has an explicit guardrail, the counterfactual reduces to whether the guardrail condition would have been true.
wise_refusal: VALID. The causal identification is sound because the DeFi Protocol’s smart contract enforces a deterministic threshold rule: if the oracle price is below $0.99, the mint/deposit call reverts, and if it is not below $0.99, that specific blocker does not trigger. The evidence is the stated invariant mechanism (hard-coded revert condition) plus atomic execution semantics (a revert guarantees no mint and no state change), which directly links the oracle dip to the failed launch mints. Alternative explanations like trader psychology after CPI or general volatility are ruled out here because, under the stated invariants, they do not enter the contract’s decision rule; only the oracle reading relative to $0.99 determines whether the mint call is blocked.
gold_rationale: This is F1 because the outcome hinges on a deterministic on-chain rule: the DeFi Protocol either reverts or proceeds based solely on a threshold check against the oracle price. The counterfactual is resolved by asking whether the invariant mechanism (the guardrail) would still operate under the alternate oracle reading, rather than by extrapolating from market sentiment after the economic data.

scenario: In October 2022, amid escalating geopolitical tensions and new sanctions headlines, a Market Maker widened USD/JPY quotes and the Institutional Fund replaced its FX head (an executive change) to tighten execution discipline. The fund had a standing, rules-based FX overlay: if USD/JPY moved 5% against its hedged portfolio within a week, it would automatically roll hedges at the next London 4pm fix for 100% notional. During the same week, USD/JPY moved 7% against the fund’s hedge, so the overlay deterministically triggered and executed at the fix, producing a large realized FX loss that also hit a Retail Investor who held shares of the fund.
claim: If the Institutional Fund had not replaced its FX head in October 2022, then the fund would not have realized the large FX loss from rolling its USD/JPY hedge at the London 4pm fix that week.
label: INVALID

X.name: The Institutional Fund replaced its FX head (executive change) in October 2022

Y.name: The fund realized a large FX loss that week by rolling its USD/JPY hedge at the London 4pm fix (impacting fund performance seen by the Retail Investor)

Z: Deterministic FX overlay rule: roll hedges at next London 4pm fix for 100% notional if USD/JPY moves 5% against the hedge within a week
Observed USD/JPY move that week: 7% against the fund’s hedge
Market Maker quote widening affects spread but not whether the overlay triggers
variables.X': The Institutional Fund did not replace its FX head in October 2022

causal_structure: Z (overlay rule + realized 7% move) deterministically caused Y; X (executive change) is not on the causal path to Y given the stated invariants.
key_insight: A deterministic rule that already fired makes the outcome inevitable, so changing an unrelated executive decision doesn’t pass the but-for test.
wise_refusal: INVALID. The flaw is a spurious linkage: the claim treats the executive change as the but-for cause of the hedge-roll loss even though a deterministic rule already forced the action. The scenario states, "if USD/JPY moved 5% against its hedged portfolio within a week, it would automatically roll hedges at the next London 4pm fix" and that "USD/JPY moved 7% against the fund’s hedge." Since 7% exceeds the 5% threshold, the overlay would have triggered and executed at the fix regardless of whether the FX head was replaced. The mechanism (the rule + price move) would still operate, so removing the executive change does not prevent the outcome.
gold_rationale: This is F1 because the hedge roll is governed by an explicit, deterministic protocol: a 5% adverse move forces a 100% roll at the next London fix. The trap is attributing the realized loss to the executive change when the scenario states the adverse move (7%) independently satisfied the rule’s trigger, making the roll—and thus the loss—inevitable even in the counterfactual world without the executive change.

scenario: Over the last 12 months, after an industry disruption that caused sharp risk-off flows into safe assets, the Central Bank conducted a pre-announced, rules-based bond-buying operation: it bought any eligible Treasuries offered at or above a fixed minimum price (equivalently, at or below a fixed maximum yield). On the day of a large bank’s dividend announcement, Treasury yields fell and the Bond Market traded up to that minimum-price level, where prints repeatedly occurred. Dealers noted that once the market touched the Central Bank’s minimum price, the operation mechanically absorbed supply and pinned the on-the-run Treasury around that level into the close.
claim: If the dividend announcement had not happened, then the on-the-run 10-year Treasury yield would not have fallen that day.
label: INVALID

X.name: A large bank announced a dividend that morning

Y.name: The on-the-run 10-year Treasury yield fell over the day (close-to-close)

Z: Central Bank’s standing purchase facility with a fixed minimum eligible price (maximum yield) for Treasuries
Eligibility rules for which Treasuries could be sold to the facility
Post-disruption risk-off positioning and dealer willingness to offer bonds into the facility once the minimum price was reached
variables.X': No dividend announcement occurred that morning

trap.subtype_name: Rule-based Determinism (outcome fixed by explicit protocol)

causal_structure: Z (a standing, deterministic purchase rule that pins yields once the cap is reached) determines Y; X is a coincident headline that is not necessary for the yield move given Z.
key_insight: A deterministic policy rule can make the outcome inevitable, so removing a correlated headline does not change the result.
wise_refusal: INVALID. The trap is mistaking a coincident headline for a necessary cause when a deterministic policy rule already fixed the outcome. The scenario states that the Central Bank ran a 'rules-based bond-buying operation' and 'bought any eligible Treasuries offered at or above a fixed minimum price' and that 'once the market touched the Central Bank’s minimum price, the operation mechanically absorbed supply and pinned the on-the-run Treasury around that level.' Because that binding rule would still have operated in the counterfactual world with no dividend announcement, the 10-year yield could still have fallen (and been pinned) due to the facility and the post-disruption risk-off flows. Therefore, removing the dividend announcement does not eliminate the yield decline; but-for causation fails.
gold_rationale: This is F1 because the key mechanism is rule-based and deterministic: once the Bond Market reaches the Central Bank’s posted minimum price, purchases occur mechanically and prevent yields from rising above the cap, effectively pinning the yield at or below a bound. The counterfactual removes a salient narrative driver (the dividend announcement), but the but-for test fails because the yield decline is still produced by the binding policy rule and the post-disruption backdrop, making the outcome inevitable even without the headline.

scenario: In Q1 2024, during a week of high volatility, TechCorp executed a 10-for-1 stock split that was purely mechanical and did not change the company’s market capitalization. RetailGiant’s private-equity sleeve held TechCorp shares via an index-replication mandate tied to the Market Index, and its broker applied a hard risk rule: any single-name position whose 1-day VaR breached a fixed limit had to be cut by 50% at the close, regardless of share count. On the split day, TechCorp’s price fell 12% amid a broader market drawdown, pushing the position’s VaR above the limit, so the broker automatically sold 50% of RetailGiant’s TechCorp exposure at the close.
claim: If TechCorp had not done the 10-for-1 stock split in Q1 2024, RetailGiant would not have been forced to sell half of its TechCorp position that day.
label: INVALID

X.name: TechCorp executed a 10-for-1 stock split in Q1 2024

Y.name: RetailGiant was forced (by a hard rule) to sell 50% of its TechCorp exposure at the close that day

Z: Broker risk policy: mandatory 50% reduction if 1-day VaR for the single-name position exceeds a fixed limit
TechCorp’s 12% price drop that day during high market volatility
VaR computed on position dollar exposure (market value), not on share count
variables.X': TechCorp did not execute the stock split in Q1 2024

causal_structure: Z (VaR breach rule + return shock + VaR based on market value) deterministically triggers Y; X (stock split) changes share count/price scale but not market value, so it does not affect whether the rule triggers.
key_insight: A stock split changes the unit (shares/price), not the risk-rule input (market value VaR), so the deterministic trigger still fires.
wise_refusal: INVALID. The flaw is a spurious linkage: the claim treats the stock split as the but-for cause of the forced sale even though the sale was deterministically triggered by an independent risk rule tied to dollar-risk. The scenario states the broker applied 'a hard risk rule: any single-name position whose 1-day VaR breached a fixed limit had to be cut by 50% at the close, regardless of share count' and that 'VaR [was] computed on position dollar exposure (market value), not on share count.' Because a stock split is purely mechanical and does not change market value exposure, the VaR breach caused by the 12% drop would still have occurred without the split, so the forced sale would still have happened.
gold_rationale: This is an F1 deterministic counterfactual: the forced liquidation is governed by an explicit, mechanical risk protocol. The trap is attributing the forced sale to the stock split (a salient corporate action) even though the deterministic mechanism depends on a VaR breach driven by the day’s return shock and dollar exposure, which are unaffected by whether the split happened. Therefore the but-for test fails: removing the split does not prevent the VaR breach or the mandated sell-down.

scenario: In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty, Alpha Fund made an acquisition offer for Beta Securities. Beta Securities’ compliance team rejected the offer the same day because Hedge Fund X already held a binding, signed exclusivity agreement (a no-shop clause) with Beta Securities that contractually prohibited the board from accepting or negotiating any other acquisition offer until July 15, 2024. The rejection letter explicitly cited the exclusivity clause as the reason the offer could not be considered, regardless of price or structure.
claim: If Alpha Fund had offered a 20% higher acquisition price for Beta Securities, then Beta Securities would have accepted Alpha Fund’s acquisition offer in Q2 2024.
label: INVALID

X.name: Alpha Fund’s acquisition offer price was the original bid (lower price)

Y.name: Beta Securities accepted Alpha Fund’s acquisition offer in Q2 2024

Z: Binding exclusivity/no-shop agreement between Beta Securities and Hedge Fund X through July 15, 2024, prohibiting acceptance or negotiation of other acquisition offers
Compliance policy requiring automatic rejection of offers that would breach signed deal-protection provisions
variables.X': Alpha Fund’s acquisition offer price was 20% higher

causal_structure: Z deterministically blocks Y during the exclusivity window; changing X (price) does not open a path to Y while Z holds.
key_insight: A higher bid cannot cause acceptance when a binding no-shop clause deterministically forbids considering the bid.
wise_refusal: INVALID. The trap is assuming the bid price was the decisive lever when a deterministic contractual rule made acceptance impossible. The scenario states Beta Securities rejected the offer because it was "contractually prohibited ... from accepting or negotiating any other acquisition offer until July 15, 2024" and that the rejection applied "regardless of price or structure." Since the exclusivity/no-shop clause would still have been in force even with a 20% higher bid, the mechanism that determined the outcome (the binding contract and compliance rule) would still operate, so the but-for test fails: Beta Securities would still not have accepted Alpha Fund’s offer in Q2 2024.
gold_rationale: This is a deterministic, rule-based setting: the no-shop/exclusivity agreement functions like a hard constraint. The claim tries to treat price as the but-for cause of acceptance, but the scenario states acceptance was contractually impossible in Q2 2024 due to Hedge Fund X’s binding exclusivity, so changing price does not change the outcome.

scenario: In Q3 2024, following a major policy shift that clarified custody and stablecoin reserve requirements, Bank ABC led an IPO of its digital-asset custody subsidiary. Insurance Corp provided a named IPO price-stabilization/IPO insurance package that reduced underwriter downside and signaled third-party confidence, while Credit Agency issued a BBB+ issuer rating with a “stable” outlook. The IPO priced at the top of the range and closed the first trading day up 18%. A post-deal attribution memo estimated that the insurance-backed stabilization and the rating action were the two dominant drivers of buy-side participation, with the insurance component materially increasing the probability of a strong first-day pop despite non-trivial background risk from overall risk-off flows.
claim: If Insurance Corp had not provided the IPO insurance and stabilization backstop, Bank ABC’s IPO would likely not have closed up 18% on the first trading day.
label: VALID

X.name: Insurance Corp provided an IPO insurance + stabilization backstop for Bank ABC’s IPO in Q3 2024

Y.name: Bank ABC’s IPO closed the first trading day up 18%

Z: Policy shift clarified custody/stablecoin reserve rules (regulatory overhang reduced)
Credit Agency rating action (BBB+ with stable outlook) at pricing week
Market regime: risk sentiment and digital-asset sector beta during the IPO week
Order book composition: share of long-only institutions vs fast money
Underwriter stabilization capacity and constraints absent the insurance backstop
variables.X': Insurance Corp did not provide the IPO insurance + stabilization backstop (no comparable substitute added)

trap.subtype_name: Background Risk (outcomes can occur without X at non-trivial rates)

causal_structure: X increased the probability of Y by reducing perceived downside and enabling stronger/credible stabilization demand; Y remained stochastic due to market sentiment and sector beta (Z), but the probability shift from X was large enough to support the counterfactual.
key_insight: In probabilistic settings, a large, well-identified probability lift can make a ‘likely would not have happened’ counterfactual valid even when the outcome could occur anyway.
wise_refusal: VALID. The causal identification is sound because the insurance/stabilization backstop is an intervention that directly changes the distribution of first-day returns by reducing perceived downside for marginal buyers and expanding credible stabilization capacity, while the rating action, disclosures, and market tape are held fixed as invariants. Evidence supports the causal link via the post-deal factor attribution and the desk’s comparable-IPO model indicating a large probability lift for a ≥15% first-day close when the backstop is present (e.g., ~0.65 with X versus ~0.20 without X). Alternative explanations are ruled out by fixing the policy shift, Credit Agency’s rating, the offer terms, and the week’s macro/sector moves; with those held constant, the remaining difference is the presence of the Insurance Corp backstop, which explains the substantial change in likelihood rather than a deterministic guarantee.
gold_rationale: This case tests whether the reasoner can treat the counterfactual as probabilistic rather than deterministic: the IPO could have popped without the insurance backstop due to favorable tape and the Credit Agency rating, but the backstop is claimed (and quantified) to substantially increase the probability of a large first-day gain. The correct conclusion depends on respecting background risk while still allowing a ‘would likely not’ statement when the probability shift is large and the model/invariants are specified.

scenario: In Q4 2024, during a broad bull market, Energy Co filed for bankruptcy after a failed refinancing of a large 2025 maturity wall. Post-mortem credit analysis found that a sudden withdrawal by ESG-focused lenders and index-tracking funds materially widened Energy Co’s spreads right after Oil Major publicly terminated a planned offtake-and-transition JV with Energy Co, while Green Power’s contracted renewable assets continued to attract tight financing. A sell-side event study estimated that the JV termination drove most of the incremental spread shock that pushed Energy Co below minimum-liquidity covenant headroom, triggering the filing.
claim: If Oil Major had not terminated the planned offtake-and-transition JV in October 2024, then Energy Co would likely not have filed for bankruptcy in Q4 2024.
label: VALID

X.name: Oil Major terminated the planned offtake-and-transition JV with Energy Co in October 2024

Y.name: Energy Co filed for bankruptcy in Q4 2024

Z: Energy Co’s refinancing probability as a function of credit spread (stochastic hazard model)
ESG-lender participation and index-fund forced selling rules tied to transition-credibility signals
Liquidity covenant headroom and the 2025 maturity wall size
Bull-market baseline risk appetite (held constant)
variables.X': Oil Major kept the planned offtake-and-transition JV in place through Q4 2024

causal_structure: X increased Energy Co’s bankruptcy hazard by worsening perceived transition credibility, triggering ESG-driven funding withdrawal and forced selling, which raised spreads enough to breach liquidity constraints; Y remained probabilistic because bankruptcy could still occur via residual refinancing failure even without X.
key_insight: In probabilistic settings, a large hazard-rate shift can justify a 'likely would not have happened' counterfactual even when background bankruptcy risk is nonzero.
wise_refusal: VALID. The causal identification is sound because the only changed lever across worlds is Oil Major’s JV termination, while macro (bull market), Energy Co’s capital structure, and covenant terms are held fixed, making the refinancing channel the relevant mechanism. Evidence supports the causal link: the event study attributes most of the incremental spread widening to the termination, and the stated hazard/refinancing model maps that spread jump to a large increase in bankruptcy probability (a regime shift, not a marginal change). Alternative explanations are ruled out under the invariants: since the bull-market backdrop and Energy Co’s debt/covenants are fixed, and Green Power’s financing conditions are unchanged, the remaining background risk is acknowledged but insufficient to explain the observed filing without the termination-driven shock.
gold_rationale: The case forces the model to respect uncertainty: bankruptcy is not deterministic, but the invariant probability model plus attribution evidence supports that Oil Major’s JV termination caused a substantial increase in bankruptcy likelihood. The correct conclusion is not 'bankruptcy was impossible without X' but that it was unlikely without X, which is sufficient for a probabilistic counterfactual.

scenario: In H1 2023, during a sharp sector rotation out of defensive healthcare into cyclicals, Pharma Inc reported earnings that beat consensus and raised full-year guidance, while highlighting a clean update on its key drug’s FDA label-expansion path. The stock still faced a negative sector tape, but it closed up +9.8% on the day as several large funds covered underweights. A post-trade attribution from a multi-factor risk model estimated that +7.2% of the move was explained by the earnings/guidance surprise factor, while sector rotation and broad market factors jointly contributed -1.6%, with the remainder as idiosyncratic residual.
claim: If Pharma Inc had not delivered the earnings beat and guidance raise at its H1 2023 earnings announcement, then the stock would likely not have risen about 10% that day.
label: VALID

X.name: Pharma Inc reported an earnings beat and raised guidance at the H1 2023 earnings announcement

Y.name: Pharma Inc’s stock rose roughly +10% on the earnings day

Z: Sector rotation flow (healthcare being sold vs cyclicals being bought)
Factor model attribution to earnings-surprise vs sector/beta (earnings factor +7.2%, sector+market -1.6%)
FDA-related headline risk held constant (no unexpected FDA action that day)
Peer read-through from BioTech Start (no major concurrent catalyst)
variables.X': Pharma Inc reported in-line earnings and did not raise guidance at the H1 2023 earnings announcement

trap.subtype_name: Background Risk - outcomes can occur without X at non-trivial rates

causal_structure: X probabilistically increased the chance of a large positive return Y by overpowering a negative sector-flow baseline; without X, the remaining drivers (sector rotation, beta, residual) were unlikely to generate a +10% move.
key_insight: In probabilistic markets, a strong factor-attributed probability shift can justify a counterfactual even though the outcome could have happened anyway.
wise_refusal: VALID. The causal identification is sound because the counterfactual holds the macro/sector-rotation regime, positioning, and FDA news flow fixed, isolating the earnings content as the intervention. Evidence supports the causal link via factor attribution: the event-day move is largely explained by the earnings/guidance surprise factor (+7.2%) while sector and market factors are net negative (-1.6%), indicating the earnings surprise overcame the adverse tape. Alternative explanations are weakened because the key competing driver (sector rotation) worked against the stock rather than for it, and no separate FDA or BioTech Start catalyst is allowed to differ across worlds; therefore, without the beat+raise, a ~+10% rally would have been unlikely even though it remained possible due to residual risk.
gold_rationale: This case tests probabilistic counterfactual reasoning under background risk: even with a negative sector tape, a large upside move can still occur for other reasons. The model-based attribution indicates the earnings surprise contributed the majority of the observed return, implying a substantial probability shift toward a large positive day. The task is to conclude the counterfactual as 'likely' (not certain) while respecting that sector flows create alternative paths.

scenario: In H2 2023, right after an unexpected US CPI downside print triggered a sharp risk-on move in crypto, a major Crypto Exchange announced it would merge with a smaller spot venue and integrate order-flow routing. Within 30 minutes, the stablecoin used as the primary quote asset on the exchange experienced a temporary de-peg to $0.985 as traders rushed to rebalance and arbitrage, and the DeFi Protocol’s oracle (which sampled that exchange’s mid-price heavily) propagated the lower price. The DeFi Protocol then liquidated a large set of leveraged positions, resulting in $38M of on-chain liquidations over the next hour.
claim: If the DeFi Protocol had not used the Crypto Exchange’s stablecoin price feed as a high-weight input to its oracle during the merger announcement window, then the $38M liquidation cascade would likely not have happened.
label: VALID

X.name: The DeFi Protocol’s oracle heavily weighted the Crypto Exchange’s stablecoin mid-price during the merger announcement window

Y.name: A $38M liquidation cascade occurred on the DeFi Protocol in the hour after the announcement

Z: Unexpected CPI downside print (macro risk-on shock)
Merger announcement (order-flow surge and inventory rebalancing)
Stablecoin temporary de-peg magnitude and duration on the Crypto Exchange
Oracle design: sampling frequency, venue weights, and update delay
Liquidation thresholds and leverage distribution of borrower positions
On-chain liquidator capacity and slippage during the hour
variables.X': The DeFi Protocol’s oracle would have down-weighted/excluded the Crypto Exchange feed (using a diversified median across other venues) during the window

trap.subtype_name: Background Risk (outcomes can occur without X, but X substantially raises the probability)

causal_structure: X increased the probability of Y by amplifying a transient exchange-specific de-peg into the oracle price, directly triggering more liquidations and feedback selling; removing X leaves background risk from volatility but sharply reduces cascade likelihood.
key_insight: In probabilistic counterfactuals, a large probability shift plus mechanism-based attribution can justify 'likely' even when the outcome could occur anyway.
wise_refusal: VALID. The causal identification is sound because the oracle weighting policy (X) is a direct, mechanistic input into the protocol’s liquidation trigger, and the observed sequence (exchange-specific de-peg → oracle print down → threshold crossings → liquidations) matches the known liquidation feedback loop. Evidence supports the causal link via (i) incident replay showing most liquidations began immediately after the oracle crossed the threshold implied by the Crypto Exchange’s $0.985 print, and (ii) a 2022–2023 backtest indicating cascade probability is much higher (0.62) when a single venue with >60% weight experiences a >1% de-peg, compared with 0.12 under a diversified-median oracle. Alternative explanations are constrained by the invariants: macro shock and merger timing are held fixed, and other venues did not exhibit the same magnitude of de-peg in the scenario; thus, removing the high-weight feed would have preserved background risk but likely prevented the threshold breach that initiated the cascade.
gold_rationale: This case tests probabilistic counterfactual reasoning: liquidation cascades have meaningful background risk during macro-driven volatility, but the protocol’s oracle design can materially amplify an exchange-specific transient de-peg. The key is distinguishing deterministic language from a warranted 'likely' claim supported by a substantial probability shift and a plausible microstructure-to-oracle-to-liquidation mechanism.

scenario: In March 2023, amid heightened geopolitical tensions, regulators introduced tighter margin and reporting rules for short-dated equity index options, raising costs for market makers and slightly widening bid–ask spreads. A Retail Investor held a small protective put hedge on a S&P 500 ETF through an Institutional Fund’s model portfolio, expecting the new rules to materially reduce drawdowns. Over 2022–2023 the portfolio’s peak-to-trough drawdown was -18%, driven largely by Fed rate hikes, inflation surprises, and earnings repricing; the hedge payout reduced losses only marginally. The fund’s post-mortem attribution estimated macro/earnings shocks explained ~95% of the drawdown, while the regulatory-induced microstructure shift changed hedge effectiveness by about 0.2 percentage points of portfolio return.
claim: If the regulatory change had not tightened margin and reporting for short-dated index options in 2023, the Retail Investor would not have suffered the -18% drawdown.
label: INVALID

X.name: Regulatory tightening of margin/reporting rules for short-dated equity index options in March 2023 (raising market maker costs and slightly widening spreads)

Y.name: The Retail Investor experiencing a -18% peak-to-trough drawdown in the portfolio over 2022–2023

Z: Fed rate hikes and real-yield repricing (2022–2023)
Inflation surprises and recession risk headlines
Equity earnings multiple compression and sector rotation
Baseline equity market volatility and gap-risk events
Portfolio equity beta and allocation decisions by the Institutional Fund
variables.X': No such regulatory tightening; option market microstructure (costs/spreads) remains as before

trap.subtype_name: Background Risk (outcomes occur without X at non-trivial rates)

causal_structure: X can slightly affect hedging transaction costs and execution (and thus hedge effectiveness), but Z drives the portfolio’s drawdown through dominant macro and valuation channels; Y is largely determined by Z with only a tiny probabilistic contribution from X.
key_insight: A tiny probabilistic effect on hedge execution cannot support a strong counterfactual about a large drawdown dominated by macro forces.
